story:
THE SHOW 2014

67 students studying BA Fine Arts at UWE are graduating this summer and need your help to put on the most amazing degree show Spike Island has ever seen!! Your contribution will help to go toward making a publication showcasing all the artists.

Help us reach our £1000 Goal

By donating toward our £1000 goal you will be massively helping us out. However small a contribution you can make, it will all add up and help us reach our goal. The publication is a very important part of the degree and doesn't come cheap. It is a great thing to give out at THE SHOW and can be important for potential future opportunities as well. 
You can help us even more by passing on this link to others that may want to support us.

story:
*Until we hit our first stretch goal, the lands you'll receive are basic lands, (Plains, Island, Swamp, Mountain, Forest)


We want to thank Liz Bailey for the song in the video. You can find her work here: http://www.bombadeerstudios.com/


This Holiday Season, Give The Gift Of Charity, And Receive Art In Return!

Let's start a holiday tradition! Magic, the Gathering is an awesome, fun, social, and educational card game. Any of us can spin elaborate tales of awesome Friday nights huddled around a kitchen table with friends, winning that Friday night Magic, or that subtly sweet toxic fume of a freshly cracked pack of cards. We owe a lot to Magic, and they receive our money for it..... lots of money. Wow, Magic has become expensive!


It's become so expensive, that a lot of people can't afford it. Heck, a lot of people can't afford FOOD this holiday season. Therefore, we at Art Traders Unlimited suggest we start a holiday tradition; lets use the creative community to bring a little holiday cheer to the unfortunate!


  • Art Trader's Unlimited is an art brokering company. One of our specialties is brokering commissions between artists who specialize in altering Magic, the Gathering cards, and potential clients.
  • We believe artists who graffiti, alter, or paint on top of Magic, the Gathering cards use these cards as a canvas. Therefore, their new works fall under the "Fair Use" clause of copyright law.
  • We DO NOT support duplicating copyrighted material! This takes away from the value of the original product, supports criminal activity, and makes life more difficult for the creative community.



Absolutely! Artists have been modifying Magic the Gathering cards ever since they've been printed. There's a booming secondary art community featuring thousands of hand crafted works. To create these works, an artist will do the following:

  • The artist will begin by purchasing the card from a vendor. Most of the time, these are purchased using online storefronts such as ChannelFireball, Starcity Games, Tcgplayer, etc.
  • Once received, the artist will scan the card, and create a photoshop design of the new artwork they want placed on the card.
  • When finished, the artist will either print a foil laminate, or a template which the artist can then paint on the card.
  • Finally, artists will generally spray a layer of satin spray paint to protect the new work.



For this holiday season's alters, we've commissioned an artist to create Holographic Overlay alters. These create the most playable, professional, and *CONSISTENT* looking  prints. Printed on the same material as a holographic trading card:

  • The holographic foil material is between 25-50 microns thick. The new work has the exact same characteristics as a traditional foil Magic, the Gathering card.
  • Between the added art, and the original card face, there is a subtle "lip". This is left in for counterfeit detection, (a counterfeit won't have a lip between the added art, and the original card face). As long as the card is played in a sleeve, it will have an unmarked surface.
  • The added art is laminated by hand to the card face using the same adhesives used on a traditional foil card. This allows it to have the exact same playing characteristics that will last for years to come!



NO!

    Wizards of the Coast, other than originally printing the card which we purchase, is in no way involved. They have a strict, "no comment", policy in regards to all secondary market art products involving their products. We use these cards as a canvas we legally purchased from the secondary market.


    BRING ON THE LEGAL!

    * These cards are not manufactured, or licensed by Wizards of the Coast. These are NOT an official product. These artists purchase the original Magic the Gathering card from a vendor, and then graffiti the face of it. This creates a new, fair use work that is separate from the copyright of the unaltered original. These works fall under the legal guidelines of "fair use" created works, and are legal to purchase, sell, and trade within and outside the United States. These are not new trading card, proxy, or counterfeit products. The original copyrighted Magic the Gathering card acts as commercially purchased canvas for the media you are purchasing. This is stated in section 107 of USA Copyright law.

    * Magic the Gathering is a registered trademark of Wizards of the Coast/Hasbro, all rights reserved. We do not state ownership of any trademarks they claim.

    * The current tournament legality of all altered art products is the following:

    MAGIC: THE GATHERING TOURNAMENT RULES
    Effective July 1, 2009
    Section 3.3 Authorized Cards: Artistic modifications are acceptable, provided that the modifications do not make the card unrecognizable or contain substantial strategic advice. THE HEAD JUDGE IS THE FINAL AUTHORITY ON ACCEPTABLE CARDS FOR A TOURNAMENT

    In addition, we don't warrant or claim responsibility for any future rules or legal changes.



    Season's Greetings is a reward. By donating to a charity this holiday season, we will send you these alters, absolutely free!

    All proceeds generated by this campaign will be divided to the following parties:

    * Please note, this is POST transaction fees. This may include transaction fees, shipping, indiegogo, legal, etc.

    (Some pledge goals have options to donate larger percentages to charity. PLEASE refer to the descriptions to see which portion goes to who!)

    • 50% of all proceeds will go to the artist responsible for manufacturing these works of art, (Artist cut). This includes various material costs.
    • 50% will be donated evenly to the following charities:



    Doctors Without Borders is leading the forefront of combating Ebola. This directly lessens suffering throughout the world, leading to a better tomorrow for all mankind.



    The Boys and Girls Clubs of America's mission is to enable ALL young people, especially those in need, to reach their full potential as productive, caring, and responsible citizens. They offer a safe place to learn and grow, relationships with caring adult professionals, and life-enhancing programs.

    Working to make the world better for children. 91% of all donations go directly to those in need. UNICEF does whatever it takes to save and protect the world's most vulnerable children.


    BRING FORTH THE STRETCH GOALS!

    Our stretch goals will be in two batches:


    BEFORE DECEMBER 15th:

    - Stretch goals met before December 15th will be shipped with holiday orders.

    AFTER DECEMBER 15th:

    - Those of you doing the Late-Turkey will receive your stretch goals on-time. Those of you who donated for Christmas shipping will receive any additional stretch goal bonuses via standard shipping with the other orders. YOU WILL GET TWO PACKAGES FROM US! This way, we can continue our stretch goals beyond the holidays!

    0-999.99$

    You'll receive the designs on basic lands. (Plains, Island, Swamp, Mountain, Forest) Come on 'yall, we can do better than that!

    1,000$


    Once we hit 1,000$, instead of five altered basic lands, they will be upgraded to SNOW COVERED LANDS! Depending on availability, you may receive an Ice Age, or Coldsnap snow-covered land.


    5,000$


    If we somehow reach 5,000$, we will include a sixth alter; Sol Ring. Actual set is subject to availability!


    10,000$

     
    5,000$ to charity would make an incredible difference if we could meet it. We would include a sixth alter. Once we reach our second goal, we'll reveal what the card is.

    Here's a couple of hints:

    - The artwork is Black Friday related, and hilarious!
    - The card is awesome in EDH!
    - It's a red card, and VERY flavorful!

    We have twenty more holiday-related designs that can be used! Once we meet a stretch goal, we will include a new one, and reveal the additional included alter! After 10,000$, we'll start doubling the number of extra alters, (so two per stretch goal instead of just one!)

    Risks & Challenges

     Originally, we wanted to donate boxes of Commander 2014 to a local charity.

    The reality?

    MTG is a card game that brings a lot of happiness, but it doesn't prevent disease, feed families, or provide warmth on a cold winter night, (Other than burning the deck!) We have so many happy collective memories involving the game, however it's basic logistics. 30$ can feed a family for a week, or they can receive a trading card game. To us, the decision is clear.

    If you really want to spread that happiness, instead of going to your local shop one weekend each month, take your decks to your local Boys & Girls club, and donate your old decks. Offer to run a class teaching these wonderful kids the game. I guarantee you'll see a lot of smiling faces, (well, at least more than your local FNM).

    It doesn't end with Magic! Bring your board games, and mentor those in need.

    You can make a difference, no matter how small you try!

    Other Ways You Can Help


    • PLEASE! Help by promoting this campaign! This is a non-profit fundraiser, so our funds are VERY tight! (If we hire someone to do promotion, less will go to charity!)
    • Please, use the Indiegogo share tools!

story: The money raised will be used to fund me on an arts focused trip to New York City. I am an 8th grade art student with goals of becoming an art teacher. This trip to NYC is an opportuntiy of a lifetime. We will visit museums, get behind the scenes tours, see Broadway shows, visit the 911 memorial and experience life in the big city. All the students going need to raise their own funds. I want to share my talents with people who are willing to contribute to my cause. Thank you for your time and generosity.

All the students going need to raise their own funds. I want to share my talents with people who are willing to contribute to my cause. Thank you for your time and generosity.

story:
Short Summary

When you live with epilepsy there are a lot of things you can't do because it isn't safe, but for me, the loss of independence has always been the kicker. That's why I want to do this walk alone. I want to experience independence on a grand scale, just me and God in the wilderness (with an emergency beacon to appease the people who care about me).

When I asked to use my study leave to go on a pilgrimage, I didn't think the 5 weeks would be approved. I'm not sure why I thought that, but I did. Next thing I knew, it was happening and the flights were booked. I take off on the 22nd April and return on the 26th May 2019.

It turns out that going on a pilgrimage is expensive, and I did not get the funding I had hoped for. Add to that the cost of medical insurance, the emergency beacon I need to carry and the terrible Canadian Dollar to Euro exchange rate...well lets just say my estimation of the costs were way off.

What I Need & What You Get

Someone told me recently that it would be good to have a cottage industry when they retire and I thought, "I already have one," I am an artist!

Creativity, art and carving are meditative for me and so I am flogging my wares to raise money. I hope you will support me. You will receive the reward you choose, updates from the trail and an invite to the show of works that I will complete during and on my return later this year. This show will be streamed via my Facebook page for those of you who can't be there in person.

What are the costs:

  • I have been advised that I need to allow $50 a day for food and accommodation in hostels along the way: $1,650
  • I will be using the train from Paris to Le Puy, Cahors to St. Jean-Pierre du Pont and at the end from Santiago to Madrid airport
  • My insurance as someone with a existing medical condition is $380
  • The emergency beacon I will be carrying is $600 for the duration of the trip
  • Supplies, equipment, communications $500 

The Perks

  • Whichever perk you choose when you support me, you will receive some of my art work. 
  • Hand drawn, hand carved or hand weaved.
  • You can also choose discounted art pins (badges) and/or stationary bundles featuring a selection of my artworks
  • Want it all? Choose "The Whole Kit & Caboodle" and get everything on offer.
  • Everyone gets updates from the trail, an invite to the show and of course a personalized thank you from me.
  • Don't want the stuff? You can support me by hitting the pink "BACK IT" button and put in whatever amount you like.

The Impact

This campaign will be the first phase of a larger project that I am working on to write a book about active and creative prayer.

In addition as part of the art show I will be giving an artist talk about the pilgrimage, the things I noticed and how the journey influenced my work and prayer life. I will also be speaking about what it is like to live with epilepsy and how it has influenced my work to date.

  • This is not my first project, so it isn't money down the drain!
  • I am working with an organization that actively promotes artists living with disabilities and have given artist talks with them to speak about living and creating with epilepsy.

Risks & Challenges

  • Many people have questioned whether I should be walking the Camino, but I am determined. If I have a seizure while I am travelling I have good insurance coverage, an emergency beacon if I am in an isolated area, and I will be carrying a medical alert in English, French and Spanish so that people will know how to help me if need be.
  • My neurologist supports me and told me to go for it! Do it while I can!
  • If I don't meet my fundraising goal I will go anyway, the flights are booked! However, I am hopeful that this project will help offset the costs of my journey. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't want the stuff? You can support me by hitting the pink "BACK IT" button and put in whatever amount you like.

Thank you for taking a look. Please share with your friends on social media, forward it to anyone that might be interested, or join my mailing list to get an invite to the show. If you can't support this venture financially, help me make some noise about it.

If you're someone who prays, I ask you to pray for me while I prepare and go on this pilgrimage.

Peace to you,

Lucy

story:
Transmigration

After traveling for dusty miles, a seat on a sculpture in the desert is welcome...Better yet, if there's a performance for entertainment...We have both to offer you and we just need some help leaving the midwest behind and transporting this 11 foot x 11 foot by 15 foot wood sculpture from Chicago to Black Rock City.

My name is Jyl Bonaguro and I am a sculptor and playwright. I designed this sculpture based upon a wing in flight. After many months of small scale models, my team and I finally have completed the full scale sculpture in wood along with a test build at a Chicago park. LED lighting is in process and we are super excited about placing it on the playa.

How you can help

Our team has funded the majority of the sculpture, but...

Our goal is to raise $1,500 to cover:

Transport and RV fees to the playa. It's a big piece that needs to be packed up and driven almost 2,000 miles. $1,500 will help offset expenses for our RV and gas.

Here's what your donations mean to us. Everything counts. I have been working with BAAAHS Chicago and San Francisco to bring Transmigration to Burning Man 2018 for the past 6 months. As a professional sculptor, I have welcomed such a great group of people who have helped me every step of the way to make my dream a reality. There's nothing better than to go from a paper model at 12 inches to a full scale sculpture standing 11 feet tall. It's been awesome and a huge amount of work for me and my team of volunteers.

Why it matters

This sculpture is inspired by the myth of the Phoenix. According to the Greek historian Herodotus (b: 484 BC), the phoenix was a beautiful, mythical bird from Ethiopia with elaborate plumage. This gorgeous bird made a nest of cypress branches and then set itself on fire. After three days, the phoenix emerged from its own ashes – reborn and released from the sentence of death, able to live on forever and thus serves as a symbol of hope and renewal.

The form of Transmigration is loosely based upon this plumage, not only of wings in flight but on fire. In the apex of the triangle, the Burning Man symbol is referenced as a subtle salute to the origins for this sculpture. The word "transmigration" means to pass from one place to another in the physical sense or spiritual in the theory of reincarnation. After the sculpture has been displayed, it will be consigned to the flames and burned to the ground as a symbol of renewal.

Other ways you can help

Sometimes you just can't afford to personally give. We would be so grateful if you would consider helping out in these other ways too: 

Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign

Share the link on your personal social pages

Special Thanks

Zachary Fietsch for realizing that I live for Art and for figuring out how to help me from funding to fabrication to generally just being amazing... Jeff Zelnio for helping me with initial models in wood and for being a sounding board for advice... Ben Stroh for post production video editing and transport. Greg Slade for the generosity with his van that seems to fit everything and then some...The rest of my Chicago based team Peter Winkler, Shorty Belle, Aaron Oppenheimer, Jeff Krucek, Therron Ricks, Ted Barrus, Solomon Hursey, Oscar Groves, Ethel Bourbon, Bryan Thurston and Kevin Trujillo along with BAAAHS Chicago and San Francisco.

Our goal is to raise $1,500 to cover:
Transport and RV fees to the playa. It's a big piece that needs to be packed up and driven almost 2,000 miles. $1,500 will help offset expenses for our RV and gas.
Here's what your donations mean to us. Everything counts. I have been working with BAAAHS Chicago and San Francisco to bring Transmigration to Burning Man 2018 for the past 6 months. As a professional sculptor, I have welcomed such a great group of people who have helped me every step of the way to make my dream a reality. There's nothing better than to go from a paper model at 12 inches to a full scale sculpture standing 11 feet tall. It's been awesome and a huge amount of work for me and my team of volunteers.

Why it matters

This sculpture is inspired by the myth of the Phoenix. According to the Greek historian Herodotus (b: 484 BC), the phoenix was a beautiful, mythical bird from Ethiopia with elaborate plumage. This gorgeous bird made a nest of cypress branches and then set itself on fire. After three days, the phoenix emerged from its own ashes – reborn and released from the sentence of death, able to live on forever and thus serves as a symbol of hope and renewal.
The form of Transmigration is loosely based upon this plumage, not only of wings in flight but on fire. In the apex of the triangle, the Burning Man symbol is referenced as a subtle salute to the origins for this sculpture. The word "transmigration" means to pass from one place to another in the physical sense or spiritual in the theory of reincarnation. After the sculpture has been displayed, it will be consigned to the flames and burned to the ground as a symbol of renewal.


Other ways you can help
Sometimes you just can't afford to personally give. We would be so grateful if you would consider helping out in these other ways too: 
Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign
Share the link on your personal social pages


Special Thanks
Zachary Fietsch for realizing that I live for Art and for figuring out how to help me from funding to fabrication to generally just being amazing... Jeff Zelnio for helping me with initial models in wood and for being a sounding board for advice... Ben Stroh for post production video editing and transport. Greg Slade for the generosity with his van that seems to fit everything and then some...The rest of my Chicago based team Peter Winkler, Shorty Belle, Aaron Oppenheimer, Jeff Krucek, Therron Ricks, Ted Barrus, Solomon Hursey, Oscar Groves, Ethel Bourbon, Bryan Thurston and Kevin Trujillo along with BAAAHS Chicago and San Francisco.

story:
What is this project?

My name is Camila Cavalcante and I am a visual artist and teacher from Brazil settled in the UK. On International Women’s Day, 2016, I started a visual arts project that explores the idea of the female body as a confrontational space: Nós Por Todas, Portuguese for Us For All. Considering the political turmoil that has recently shaken the UK, the US and my home country of Brazil, I am interested in broadening a debate that has been taken to the streets of major Brazilian cities and echoes around the world: women’s rights.

In Brazil abortion is only legal to save the woman’s life, in the case of a foetus without a brain and in cases of rape. Despite prohibition, recent research from the Federal University of Brasilia suggests that one in five women between 14 and 40 years old have had at least one abortion in their lives. These women risk their lives undergoing unregulated procedures with pseudo doctors and no psychological support.

This project is about reaching and supporting women around the world who are being judged and prosecuted because they dared to decide what to do with their own bodies.

Us For All in 1999: "When the nurse looked at me, I felt all the weight and judgment a woman can experience for making this decision without the support of the law or public health."

What has been done already?           

For over a year I have been developing a network of women who have joined the debate to share their experiences and opinions about illegal abortion, with their identities protected. I have taken nude portraits with these women in their homes, holding and hugging them, with their back to the camera while I reveal my face, exposing my body and my identity in their name. On some of the printed photographs I made use of the written word over our bodies to give voice to their stories and to compose a political and intimate manifesto.

Nós Por Todas has been self-funded since I started the project when I was selected to take part in the Despina International Art Residency in Rio de Janeiro in 2016. I have photographed 21 women to date, 12 of them during the residency. The 12 images were exhibited in Rio during an event by Despina and they have been getting great feedback ever since. It was after the residency ended and I returned to the UK, that I realised that this is a subject that needs a lot more exposure, a lot more collaborators, a lot more debate. We need to talk about this.

You can see the photos that I have already taken here: www.camilacavalcante.com/usforall

Us For All in 2013: "Abortion is something that nobody wants to do. Nobody goes through this easily."

What is the plan?

The idea is to go back to Brazil and expand my approach, photographing more women and reaching a broader audience, so that eventually I can transform this project into a book. The network I have built is already in touch with another 50 women all over the country who are willing to collaborate with me, and this number is likely to increase. The crowdfunding campaign would help me travel to and around Brazil and reach communities of women that I haven’t yet had the opportunity to photograph. I will utilise the networks of local women’s support groups and feminist collectives that I am already in contact with to get in touch with women that are more exposed to the risks of illegal abortions: women of colour and poor women.

Also, in this project, the visual use of the written word is essential to give voice to these women, to move away from the eroticized and objectified view of the female body. You can follow the link here to accompany the project while I am working. I will be regularly posting images and quotes from my collaborators. Spread the word!

Us For All in 2000: "A public debate is fundamental to end this hypocrisy."

What do I need?

I need £2,400 to cover the minimum costs of the project, so that I can be in Brazil for at least 3 weeks photographing more women. Your support would be essential to cover my travel expenses to and around Brazil, particularly to places that are remote, and therefore more difficult and expensive to reach.

We can do this together! I need your contribution to keep this project going, to help breaking some stereotypes that are associated with these women and show that each woman should be able to decide what to do with her own body.

Any help would be greatly appreciated and if you cannot help me financially, share this campaign with your friends via email and social media or email me to help finding more collaborators to be photographed.

The more you help, the more women I can photograph! The more of these important stories are told, the more knowledge around the issue of women’s rights, the closer we get to safe and legal abortion practices.

Us For All in 2006: "I was really ill, screaming with pain. My mother was also by my side, desperate, holding my hand, not knowing what to do."

Why is this so important?

There are six bills in the Lower House of Congress and the Senate in Brazil that, amongst other things, are trying to change the constitution and define ‘life’ as beginning at conception, making abortion completely illegal.

I understand that doing an art project is not directly going to change the legislation in Brazil, or in other countries with similar issues, like Northern Ireland or the Republic of Ireland. However, the more we talk about this, the more we amplify the debate and the more we make people aware of the hypocrisies. Limiting access to legal and safe abortions or prohibiting it altogether has a lot to do with restricting women’s sexuality and disrespecting women’s human rights. It is a debate that needs to be had.

The women that I am collaborating with have been through a lot. They live under the psychological torture of not being able to express their opinions and experiences, on top of the constant fear of being judged and prosecuted. I feel very passionate about this because they are not less than any other person. They should not have to hide for deciding what is good for them. Exposing my face and my identity in their names is my way of supporting their pain and switching the focus of the judgement away from them.

Poster of the project (£25 perk)

What do you get?

  • £1 Thank you on my website and Facebook fan page.
  • £5 Wallpaper digital image of the project + Thank you on my website and Facebook fan page.
  • £10 Postcard of the project with a hand-written thank you message from me + Wallpaper image of the project + Thank you on my website and Facebook fan page.
  • £25 Poster of the project + Postcard of the project with a hand-written thank you message from me + Wallpaper image of the project + Thank you on my website and Facebook fan page.
  • £35 T-shirt with the logo of the campaign + Postcard of the project with a hand-written thank you message from me + Wallpaper image of the project + Thank you on my website and Facebook fan page. 
  • £40 One A3 print of selected images by the artist (see images below) + Postcard of the project with a hand-written thank you message from me + Wallpaper image of the project  + Thank you on my website and Facebook fan page.
  • £50 Portfolio review of 5 to 15 images of your own work via email + Postcard of the project with a hand-written thank you message from me + Wallpaper image of the project + Thank you on my website and Facebook fan page.
  • £100 One-hour photography class tailored to your own needs in London, Edinburgh or via Skype + Postcard of the project with a hand-written thank you message from me + Wallpaper image of the project + Thank you on my website and Facebook fan page.
  • £300 One hour talk about the subject and the project in your organisation in London, Edinburgh or via Skype (or with transportation otherwise organised by institution) + Poster of the project + Postcard of the project with a hand-written thank you message from me + Thank you on my website and Facebook fan page.
  • £350 One A2-sized editioned and signed selected original artwork from this project or different project agreed between the artist and the supporter + Poster of the project + Postcard of the project with a hand-written thank you message from me + Wallpaper image of the project + Thank you on my website and Facebook page.

T-shirt of the project (£35 perk)

Choices of images available for A3 print  (£40 perk)

If your company or organisation want to support this project with a larger sum and create a partnership going forward, please contact me at info@camilacavalcante.com

If you would like to collaborate with me and be one of the subjects of my portraits, please contact me on nosportodas@gmail.com

Your identity will be safe with me.

Together we are stronger!

For more information about the project, including more pictures, stories and press release please visit www.camilacavalcante.com/usforall

To see more of my work and previous projects, please visit my website: www.camilacavalcante.com

Thank you very much! Your support means a lot to me!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
A Short Summary of who we are & what we want to do

Invisible Borders Trans-African Project was established in 2009 by a group of African artists with aims to promote movement and Trans-border exchange in Africa using visual, literary and performing arts. The flagship project is the Invisible Borders Road Trip which every year unites up to 10 artists - photographers, writers, filmmakers, to make road trips across the borders of countries in Africa. During the road trip, the artists produce works, through the medium of photography, writing, film and performance art. Beyond that they also consolidate networks through outreach programs such as workshops, presentations and exhibitions while on the go.

1. A ROAD TRIP FROM LAGOS (NIGERIA)  TO SARAJEVO (BOSNIA & HERZEGOVINA)

This trip, the 5th in the series, will be the ﬁrst Transcontinental Road Trip of the collective and will be from Lagos (Nigeria) to Sarajevo (Bosnia) through 21 countries in Africa and Europe. There has hardly been a trip of this kind in the history of African art.

During the last four editions of the Road Trip the group has explored African countries from the West to the East and Central Africa. The impressions of the last four years have given rise to reﬂections and subsequent evolution of questions surrounding the complexness of borders. This year’s road trip is therefore an attempt to approach the core of what necessitates borders: Movement. The road trip project is an attempt to draw a tangible line of connection across chosen geographic locations in order to transcend the limitations proposed by the existing demarcating lines.

The road trip will assemble up to 10 artists (accompanied by 3 technical crew members)  from countries in Africa whose previous work are rooted in the reality of the African continent. It will be made up of photographers, writers, video artists, art critics, art historians and performance artists. Read about the participants.

The journey will last 151 days (22 weeks) from the 2nd of June until 31st of October 2014. Read more about the road trip


2. A BOOK ABOUT OUR FIRST FOUR ROAD TRIPS

Book Cover Design: Kummer & Hermann

In collaboration with Institut Francais,we plan to produce a book that articulates the discoveries, experiences and reflections of the first four editions of the road trip from 2009 to 2012, bringing together rich and powerful images complemented by essays from the writers that traveled on the road trip as well as by engaging scholars, art historians and curators invited to contribute.

The reader of the Invisible Borders book will enjoy fluid navigation of images and texts in different rhythms and layers amounting to a sort of a non-linear rendition of the experiences of the project, featuring images and writings from places like Nigeria,  Ghana, Mali, Chad, Sudan, Ethiopia Senegal, Cameroon, Gabon and more.

This book will find its way into libraries of schools and art institutions in the African continent and beyond. It will be out on time for our next road trip from Lagos to Sarajevo come June 2014. This gives the opportunity to distribute them along the way as we trek from Africa to Europe.

The book comes as a softcover, of 200 full colour images and approximately 320 pages and it is scheduled to be launched in April 2014.

Not only  will your contributions make this  endeavour a reality, it is symbolic of your support towards documentation of creative endeavours in Africa in this stage of the 21st century, and that is extremely historical. 



What We Need & What You Get

  • $173,600 is a lot, but that's what we need to make the road trip and book possible. This will cover the accommodation, per diem, transportation, and publishing costs. Consider donating the smallest (or largest!) fraction of this, and you'll be part of history!
  • Our perks are generous as well: you can get limited-edition DVDs, copies of the book, t-shirts, postcards, and you stand a chance to meet us during the road trip

Breakdown of costs

We’re aiming for 173,600 USD which covers:

  • $78,520: per diems (covering feeding and pocket expenses) for our artists for 22 weeks

  • $58, 890: accommodation during the road trip 

  • $12,000: printing of the book

  • $10,000: paying the designers of the book

  • $ 6,680: Indiegogo commission (4% of total)

  • $4,500: paying authors fee for the artists whose work are included in the book 

  • $3,000: payment for the driver of the Van


The Impact

We are convinced that for there to be a steadfast progress in Africa from which all countries can benefit, there must first be freedom of movement of peoples and cultures across borders. Furthermore, we hope to offer an unconventional perspective of Africa - one that has suffered under the blatancy of mass media.


Other Ways You Can Help

Remember that if you are on this page you can do something to help our cause. You can share the campaign with your network using the Indiegogo campaign tool. Or if you have any question, please email us right away (info@invisible-borders.com)

story:
Origins:


What would you do if no comprehensive resource on your research subject existed? This is exactly the dilemma I found myself in, as I was doing research on Kenyan crafts several weeks ago.

Changing my research topic would’ve been the easiest way out of the dilemma I faced. However, I see myself as belonging to a new generation of proactive young Africans who are determined to foster the change that they want to see on the African continent. So I decided to create a comprehensive resource on Kenyan crafts so that others wouldn’t experience the challenge that I had encountered.

This culminated in the launch of Crafting Kenya, a project that has a compelling public benefit angle while simultaneously offering attractive perks to contributors. My experience working on international development projects with communities around the globe has indeed prepared me for Crafting Kenya.

The Project:

Culture remains one of Africa’s greatest, yet untapped, assets. The accelerating pace of urbanization and global cultural exchanges that could potentially erode local cultures indicates a clear and urgent need for preservation.

This September I’ll travel throughout Kenya, with a professional photographer, creatively documenting Kenya's diverse traditional crafts. I’ll also look to collect the stories behind the crafts, the inspiration for their colors and symbols, and the materials and techniques used.The idea is to cover as much ground as possible, ensuring that the wealth of Kenya’s crafts is captured in images and words.

I believe that preservation needn’t be a long and bureaucratic process, and that preservation and creativity aren’t mutually exclusive.  In fact, I see the best kind of preservation as being one that transforms culture in its raw form into cultural symbols, products and images that remain present in our everyday lives, as opposed to living in documents in dusty archives that few have access to.

Public Benefit:

When I decided to launch this project, I made a conscious choice to figure out how the photographs and the information collected throughout the project would be beneficial to other people. As such, the final project delivery, a professionally designed, digital compilation of Kenya’s crafts, will be availed to:

  • University students in fields such as Design, Anthropology and History at universities in Kenya and elsewhere
  • The National Museums of Kenya
  • The Kenya Tourism Board

Our goal is to have a public exhibition of the Crafting Kenya photography at the National Museum of Kenya in Nairobi, or other Nairobi-based cultural institutions, at the end of 2014 or beginning of 2015. Crafting Kenya is also open to partnering with other cultural institutions around the world to exhibit the Crafting Kenya photographs, and put a much-needed spotlight on Kenyan crafts and the artisans who make the crafts.

What's in it for our generous contributors? 
Please see the perks section for information on Crafting Kenya's attractive perks.

This is what a professionally designed Crafting Kenya book (print and digital) could look like:

Thinking Long-Term:

“Paint a picture of the future. Go there.”-Seth Godin

Around the globe, creative and cultural industries are increasingly recognized for their significant economic and social impact. According to the US Bureau of Economic Analysis and National Endowment for the Arts, the arts and cultural production accounted for $504 billion, or 3.2% of the US GDP in 2011. A Deutsche Bank Research report indicated that Germany’s cultural and creative industries generated 60 billion euros from goods and services produced by the sector, in 2009. The sector also employed over 1 million people.

Africa’s traditional cultures, if preserved and leveraged strategically, could be a great source of valuable materials and inspiration to power economically vibrant creative and cultural industries.

As I say in the video, I belong to a generation of young Africans who are invested in redefining the future of the continent. I see this project as a small but important contribution towards this redefinition of Africa’s future.

The Photographer:

Meet Anthony Bourasseau, Crafting Kenya's photographer. Anthony is a very talented photographer with a global eye. His experience as a photographer spans over diverse cultures in Africa, Asia, Latin America, and the Caribbean. He is currently in France exhibiting photography from his travels in Cuba.

The Crafting Kenya team is excited to work with someone with his level of talent and commitment. 

How funds will be spent:

The money raised during this campaign will be used to cover administrative expenses only. All Crafting Kenya team members are volunteering their time, at no cost. Here are examples of project costs that we expect to incur:

  • Car Rental, Experienced Driver and Gas for 21-30 days: $4,000-$5,000 (Ground travel will account for the biggest project expense.)
  • Local Flights: $500 (In some cases, the team will have to travel by air.)
  • International flight: $700 (This is to bring the photographer to Kenya)
  • Accommodation: $1,500 (To cover accommodation costs for 3-4 people during the duration of the project)
  • Data Organization and Design costs: TBD (At the end of the project, design professionals will be hired to compile all the information collected in a user-friendly and attractive layout.)
  • E-book: If we surpass our funding goal, we'll definitely look into publishing an e-book.

THANK YOU!

story:
William Blake was a poet, artist and visionary, and one of the most radical thinkers the world has ever seen.  He challenged the limitations imposed upon us by Society and found a route to escape the 'mind-forg'd manacles' that limit our growth as individuals.

Blake's escape came through the creative Imagination : he went out and made things  - poetry, paintings, exquisite illuminated books ... and the means to create them.  He invented colour printing and was the first artist in England to discover the monoprint.

He vowed to build 'Jerusalem in England's green and pleasant land'  yet for Blake himself, there is no home.  We are asking you to help change this, to create an extraordinary house where dreamers, artists and visionaries might find respite on their difficult journey through this world.

The Cottage will also be your home, a place to visit, and an engine of creativity that shares the artefacts it makes with you - a family of supporters around the world.


BUYING THE COTTAGE  During his lifetime, Blake lived in nine different lodgings, and today only two of these buildings survive. One is a small Georgian house in the centre of London; the other is a Cottage by the sea in the village of Felpham on the Sussex coast. 

This is the first time the Cottage has come onto the market since 1928.  The Blake Society has negotiated a 'legal option' that means if we can raise £520,000 by the 28th of November 2014 then we can buy the Cottage and create a home for Blake and all that he stood for - creativity, imagination and 'mental fight'. 

So let's support this celebration of an artist who believed that 'Execution is the Chariot of Genius' and a man of courage who never ceased 'to kick against the pricks'!  (Acts 26:14)

To find out more about William Blake, the plan for the Cottage and this campaign, please click Blake Cottage Appeal 


REWARDS  Blake inspires so many creative artists, writers and musicians that we are asking them to create special rewards for you. Some of these gifts will be delivered digitally while others require shipping and some, of course, must await the opening of the Cottage itself.  New rewards will be announced as more artists join the Blake Cottage campaign.

THE RISKS  At the close of this Indiegogo campaign on 20 November 2014 we have raised £85,000 towards the target of £520,000 - that's 16% of the goal -  through pledges from Local Government, Grant Giving Trusts, Individual donors and Indiegogo!  Once the goal is reached, that's not the end of course; the Cottage has to be architecturally restored, but we are confident this can be achieved because we will then have the lead-time to approach many more sources of philanthropy.  The long-term economic model is robust and rests on fine-tuning a balance between the income from guests who pay to stay in the Cottage and the outgoings of offering hospitality to visionaries. In addition the public will be encouraged to visit the Cottage.

A VISION  The long term plan is to acquire Blake's London home and join the two houses through an axis of creativity that links the city to the sea, allowing work to be originated in Felpham and displayed in the capital.


LEGAL NOTE  The Blake Society was founded in 1985 and is a not-for-profit organisation and a registered charity. All the monies raised go into a designated charity bank account unique to this appeal. If the money raised should exceed the sum needed to buy the Cottage then any excess funds will be applied to its renovation and refurbishment. If the appeal should fail to reach the sum needed to buy the Cottage then all the monies donated will be used to leverage a loan to complete the purchase or to secure occasional public access to the Cottage or to Blake’s other surviving residence in London. The lawyers advising the campaign are Bircham Dyson Bell, one of the leading law firms in the UK. 


THANKS  Our gratitude to the BBC for permission to use footage from the Omnibus programme 'William Blake : Singing for England', to the actress Kelly Burke for playing Blake, and to the pianist & composer Guy Pearson. 



The Imagination is not a State : it is the Human Existence itself

story:
I Want To Help Others, Will You Help Me?

Hey There You Special Person!

   My name is Eva (Christine Alleva) Marie Maxson,… A very long name I know! I was born in the Bronx, NY, and was given up for adoption as a baby. My Biological Mother's name was Christine Alleva, and she named me after her. My Adoptive Parents named me Eva Marie Maxson, after “Eva Marie Saint”. I have found my Biological Family, and it has been awesome, seeing my Italian/Sicilian heritage, and also have found some fun, and loving people just like me!

   My Adoptive Parents Judy and John are also fun, and loving, and even though my Adoptive Father passed when I was just a little girl, they gave me the best up bringing, with the best care possible! My biological mother passed 3 yrs. before I could find her and it has been most traumatic. I am very grateful however to of found my cousins, and aunts whom I speak to, or visit on a regular basis, and have wonderful stories, I have a lot of things in common with my bio mom! She too was an artist, warm hearted, with the ambition to help people.

   

The mission, and why I ask for your help is simple.  I design locally, and want to donate my time and talent to help others reach their goal, and to help people get the help they deserve. I have had to move multiple times, renting room to room, until I met the love of my life, and have been living with him the past year and a half. And my dear sweet Mother has helped me so much, that I want to show her, and everyone else that said I couldn't do it,I can! Or rather the ones that tell me I have so much talent,"Why are you not out there doing it bigger than you have?") I love what I do, I just don’t have the means to an end to make it a full time career. My computer is running super slow, and I cannot afford a new one. I have to outsource most of my items I sell, tee-shirts, phone cases, canvas prints, and not to mention, the upgrades needed and film for cameras, for me to edit video and also the prints for “regular” freelance graphic design jobs. I do not even have the funds to start my very own professional web site! ( I design those too*) So therefor my commission is next to nothing because I cannot promote myself correctly.Or donate the things I've done because there is a date of demand. I also will be using some of the funds for my portfolio web site, shop web site, and print portfolio as well.

Over the past few years I have designed various flyers, and banners for people in need that also help others as wel. Or for fundraising events, and can’t deliver a lot of times because of lack of materials, or funds to outsource. It saddens me because I want to help those in need, not with money (if I had I would), but by spreading the word, so people who have the financial means, and want to help those who need food, food or warm coats, children the cancer treatments they need, to give hope to the weak, to one day be mighty and strong! Help me Save The Planet! Please help by donation or support or both! This is what I'm destined for. I don’t know where to go*… I really want share the importance of spreading the word of causes that don't get enough exposure.

 

Your donations will help make that possible, or at least for me to stand on my own two feet, and get the help they need directed to them. Many people are way more in need than I, it is fully noted, and understood. I can however reach out, and help to the best of my ability, and you will be helping too!!**

I have had many job searches come to a dead end, with lack of experience in my field of profession. Since I was in college for 6 years, or freelancing. Without the funds I need to “spread the word” or even print out materials to advertise my self…Well let’s just say, it hasn’t worked for me the best, and I cannot continue to sit stagnate knowing that I have a talent that can and will help others.

 

I have a great artistic eye, good sense of communication, and the self-motivation of an ox against ants. I want nothing more than to be successful, and to help others succeed as well. I believe life is a true gift, and should be cherished; there should be no regrets! This is my life’s aspiration, and means so much to me!

*Check out below to see what you can receive for your donations. If you cannot donate money, please pass it a long to friends, and family, or anyone you know would be interested in giving me the chance I need to make my life complete, and do something for the greater good! There are Indiegogo share tools that will help with sharing!

story:
For the past several years, I've enjoyed capturing the local music scene in the Tri Cities and Walla Walla.  I've taken photos of metal, punk, country, hip hop, jazz...  and pretty much every other genre you can think of.  In fact, I've captured performance photos of somewhere around 200 bands in performance since 2005.    While I focus on local acts, I've also had the opportunity to photograph nationally touring acts.

While I enjoy sharing these photos online with the bands who perform, and their fans -- I've always wanted the opportunity to display the best of this work "live" in a studio/gallery setting.   Now, the perfect opportunity has presented itself and I'd like your help in putting this exhibit together.

During the weekend of August 13, 2015 the Gentlemen of the Road tour will be coming to Walla Walla, bringing top national talent to the area including Foo Fighters, the Flaming Lips, and Mumford and Sons.   I've been offered the wall space at Main Street Studios, one of Walla Walla's top music venues and the host to music industry VIP events during the tour's stop-over.  

Our hope is to put together a collection of 10-20 large (3x5 foot), high-impact concert photos for the walls of Main St Studios.  The exhibit will be mounted in time for visiting music industry people to see them but will remain through the end of the year.

Like my concert photography itself, this is a labor of love -- I can't offer anything in return but my gratitude and continued devotion to documenting our local scene.  Any contribution, large or small, will help -- and will be appreciated!

story:
STAR WARS. It lies at the very foundation of modern popular culture. For those of us born around 1970 it IS popular culture. Its reach in our shared cultural mind is almost total.

As a person who grew up with STAR WARS as a guiding light, I feel that this incredible piece of cinema contains all of the lessons we need to help the human species build a brighter future and a thriving, morally conscious civilization.

By assuming the perspective of DARTH VADER I feel that the human race can finally come to comprehend the nature of evil and the many ways it can grow unseen in the human heart.

This is lesson I hope to explore with my new series of epic paintings titled: SANDSTORM.

My name is Chris Woods. I am a professional artist living and working in Chilliwack, BC, Canada (about 90 minutes east of Vancouver). I was born in 1970 and I have lived in Chilliwack since 1979.

My paintings over the last twenty-four years have looked at the far-reaching effects of mass-produced culture on the individual. They have appeared twice on the cover of Adbusters Magazine and in eighteen solo exhibitions in Canada and the United States since 1988.

Recently, I was invited to exhibit my work at The Reach Gallery Museum in Abbotsford, BC. This show, set to run in the summer of 2013, represents the first time in my twenty-four years as a visual artist that I have been asked to mount a solo exhibition in a museum setting.

www.thereach.ca

By reexamining the films that played a major role in the formative years of my generation I hope to examine what our childhood eyes may have missed.

Even though we see Darth Vader as a two-dimensional monster, his mask actually disguises a highly nuanced, and very human character. By flipping the narrative of Star Wars I intend to look beyond the hollywood cliché of depicting the battle of good vs. evil as a simple case of 'black vs. white'.

Darth Vader’s journey to the dark side serves as a meditation on the nature of evil in the modern age. It also serves as entry point into understanding the mysterious forces that can slowly erode and distort the better human qualities we all share as individuals. Vader’s life followed a tragic arc that has many parallels in history and the history of painting.

These themes will be tackled in SANDSTORM through fourteen epic-scale oil-paintings on canvas inspired by 19th century French Romantic painter Eugene Delacroix. Delacroix was obsessed with painting scenes from epics by Dante, Virgil and Shakespeare. I see the Star Wars Trilogy as the most popular myth of our time, just as Delacroix saw The Divine Comedy, The Aeneid and Hamlet as the popular myths of his time.

The paintings will be based on digital ‘screen captures’ taken from the original theatrical cuts of the Star Wars Trilogy and the ‘deleted scenes’ found on the ‘Star Wars: Complete Saga’, Blu-Ray Box-Set. The show’s title, SANDSTORM, is taken from the most famous of these deleted scenes. 

These paintings will chronicle the darkest visions and nightmares that Darth Vader may have suffered in his private moments during the events of the original Star Wars Trilogy. Even though we are used to standing beside the heroic characters of Han Solo, Luke Skywalker and Princess Leia as they fight for good, to Vader they were mysterious figures that represented the greatest threat to him and his future. To Vader they are the villains to be feared and destroyed.

In an effort to better express these themes I plan to adopt a looser, more restless style of painting. By utilizing a more agitated and expressive approach I hope to emulate the ceaseless, personal torment that Vader fought through every day.

By seeing the events of the Star Wars trilogy from Darth Vader’s perspective I feel that we can gain true insight into the circumstances that can blind any individual and twist them into an ‘agent of evil’. This is the primary role of this exciting new series.

By showing this project in a museum setting, I now have the potential to bring my work to an entirely new audience and perhaps gain the attention of the larger fine-art community.

A museum venue for a visual-artist has a tremendous impact on the minds of professional curators, art collectors and critics and it could signal a major advancement for my artistic ‘brand’.

Even without these possibilities the challenge of completing work for a museum exhibition is a large one that I must complete successfully. The invitation from The Reach Gallery Museum is an incredible honor and I must respond with every tool I have in order to create a body of work suitable for exhibition in their incredible cultural venue.

The materials and resources I require to complete the SANDSTORM project are modest but vital to the successful conclusion of this exhibition. Materials such as paint, canvas, stretcher bars, brushes, gesso, painting mediums and varnishes comprise approximately $3000 of my requested budget and constitute the very core of what I require in the studio.

I am also planning to spend approximately $2000 to upgrade some of the tools I use in my day-to-day work such as an artist’s digital projector, and a new digital SLR camera to use in the production and documentation of the paintings themselves. These items will streamline my workflow and turn days of work into hours. A new camera will also allow me to properly document The Reach Gallery Museum SANDSTORM installation, the opening ceremonies and any related events such as talks or lectures.

The pictures I work from while painting also require a large amount of printer-ink and photographic paper to bring them to life. Also needed are research materials such as books, dvd’s, and periodicals of all types. The amount needed to purchase these items for SANDSTORM is approximately $1000.

The remainder of the funds will go toward basic studio and household living expenses i.e. heat, lighting. Ten months of worry-free studio time are just as essential to producing these works, as are the oil-paint, canvas and wood that go into their construction.

Some of you may feel that your money may be poorly spent in supporting an artist unknown to you but please keep in mind that over the last twenty-four years I have completed and exhibited 18 solo shows comprising over 175 major oil-paintings, drawings and prints.

I feel that this uninterrupted record of quality output makes me ideally suited to complete the SANDSTORM series in a timely manner exactly as proposed. Lack of hard work has never been an obstacle in bringing my dreams to reality.

As a reward for your support I am offering a variety of incentives for contributions both large and small. One of the positive side effects of working on this new series is that I have been creating a large number of preliminary drawings, paintings and prints that I am eager to share with those who donate. Incentives will be offered at almost all levels from $500 to $250 to $50 to as low as $25.  

 

Those individuals who are extremely generous will be free to chose from a few of the actual painting included in the SANDSTORM series itself. 

 

If this project finds you unable to contribute in the monetary sense you can still contribute by sharing this request online with family and friends. Getting the word out about SANDSTORM is easy if you use the Indiegogo sharing tools that are available with this appeal. Any help you can give will most definitely contribute to the larger goal and it will also earn my eternal thanks.

If I do not reach the posted goal of $14,000, the funds that are raised will go first to purchasing the materials needed to complete this project and then to cover my day-to-day living expenses. Camera and projector upgrades can wait for another day.

Time and materials are the two essential elements I need to bring this series to life. My priorities will continue to remain with these fundamentals no matter the outcome of this campaign.

It has been a long time since I have been this excited about a potential new series and I am most confident that, with your help and my proven track-record, SANDSTORM will be an amazing series of paintings and an unqualified success for The Reach Gallery Museum and for myself.

Thank you.
story_txt:
STAR WARS. It lies at the very foundation of modern popular culture. For those of us born around 1970 it IS popular culture. Its reach in our shared cultural mind is almost total.
As a person who grew up with STAR WARS as a guiding light, I feel that this incredible piece of cinema contains all of the lessons we need to help the human species build a brighter future and a thriving, morally conscious civilization.
By assuming the perspective of DARTH VADER I feel that the human race can finally come to comprehend the nature of evil and the many ways it can grow unseen in the human heart.
This is lesson I hope to explore with my new series of epic paintings titled: SANDSTORM.

My name is Chris Woods. I am a professional artist living and working in Chilliwack, BC, Canada (about 90 minutes east of Vancouver). I was born in 1970 and I have lived in Chilliwack since 1979.
My paintings over the last twenty-four years have looked at the far-reaching effects of mass-produced culture on the individual. They have appeared twice on the cover of Adbusters Magazine and in eighteen solo exhibitions in Canada and the United States since 1988.

Recently, I was invited to exhibit my work at The Reach Gallery Museum in Abbotsford, BC. This show, set to run in the summer of 2013, represents the first time in my twenty-four years as a visual artist that I have been asked to mount a solo exhibition in a museum setting.

www.thereach.ca
By reexamining the films that played a major role in the formative years of my generation I hope to examine what our childhood eyes may have missed.

Even though we see Darth Vader as a two-dimensional monster, his mask actually disguises a highly nuanced, and very human character. By flipping the narrative of Star Wars I intend to look beyond the hollywood cliché of depicting the battle of good vs. evil as a simple case of 'black vs. white'.

Darth Vader’s journey to the dark side serves as a meditation on the nature of evil in the modern age. It also serves as entry point into understanding the mysterious forces that can slowly erode and distort the better human qualities we all share as individuals. Vader’s life followed a tragic arc that has many parallels in history and the history of painting.
These themes will be tackled in SANDSTORM through fourteen epic-scale oil-paintings on canvas inspired by 19th century French Romantic painter Eugene Delacroix. Delacroix was obsessed with painting scenes from epics by Dante, Virgil and Shakespeare. I see the Star Wars Trilogy as the most popular myth of our time, just as Delacroix saw The Divine Comedy, The Aeneid and Hamlet as the popular myths of his time.


The paintings will be based on digital ‘screen captures’ taken from the original theatrical cuts of the Star Wars Trilogy and the ‘deleted scenes’ found on the ‘Star Wars: Complete Saga’, Blu-Ray Box-Set. The show’s title, SANDSTORM, is taken from the most famous of these deleted scenes. 
These paintings will chronicle the darkest visions and nightmares that Darth Vader may have suffered in his private moments during the events of the original Star Wars Trilogy. Even though we are used to standing beside the heroic characters of Han Solo, Luke Skywalker and Princess Leia as they fight for good, to Vader they were mysterious figures that represented the greatest threat to him and his future. To Vader they are the villains to be feared and destroyed.
In an effort to better express these themes I plan to adopt a looser, more restless style of painting. By utilizing a more agitated and expressive approach I hope to emulate the ceaseless, personal torment that Vader fought through every day.
By seeing the events of the Star Wars trilogy from Darth Vader’s perspective I feel that we can gain true insight into the circumstances that can blind any individual and twist them into an ‘agent of evil’. This is the primary role of this exciting new series.
By showing this project in a museum setting, I now have the potential to bring my work to an entirely new audience and perhaps gain the attention of the larger fine-art community.
A museum venue for a visual-artist has a tremendous impact on the minds of professional curators, art collectors and critics and it could signal a major advancement for my artistic ‘brand’.
Even without these possibilities the challenge of completing work for a museum exhibition is a large one that I must complete successfully. The invitation from The Reach Gallery Museum is an incredible honor and I must respond with every tool I have in order to create a body of work suitable for exhibition in their incredible cultural venue.
The materials and resources I require to complete the SANDSTORM project are modest but vital to the successful conclusion of this exhibition. Materials such as paint, canvas, stretcher bars, brushes, gesso, painting mediums and varnishes comprise approximately $3000 of my requested budget and constitute the very core of what I require in the studio.
I am also planning to spend approximately $2000 to upgrade some of the tools I use in my day-to-day work such as an artist’s digital projector, and a new digital SLR camera to use in the production and documentation of the paintings themselves. These items will streamline my workflow and turn days of work into hours. A new camera will also allow me to properly document The Reach Gallery Museum SANDSTORM installation, the opening ceremonies and any related events such as talks or lectures.
The pictures I work from while painting also require a large amount of printer-ink and photographic paper to bring them to life. Also needed are research materials such as books, dvd’s, and periodicals of all types. The amount needed to purchase these items for SANDSTORM is approximately $1000.
The remainder of the funds will go toward basic studio and household living expenses i.e. heat, lighting. Ten months of worry-free studio time are just as essential to producing these works, as are the oil-paint, canvas and wood that go into their construction.
Some of you may feel that your money may be poorly spent in supporting an artist unknown to you but please keep in mind that over the last twenty-four years I have completed and exhibited 18 solo shows comprising over 175 major oil-paintings, drawings and prints.






I feel that this uninterrupted record of quality output makes me ideally suited to complete the SANDSTORM series in a timely manner exactly as proposed. Lack of hard work has never been an obstacle in bringing my dreams to reality.

As a reward for your support I am offering a variety of incentives for contributions both large and small. One of the positive side effects of working on this new series is that I have been creating a large number of preliminary drawings, paintings and prints that I am eager to share with those who donate. Incentives will be offered at almost all levels from $500 to $250 to $50 to as low as $25.  




 
Those individuals who are extremely generous will be free to chose from a few of the actual painting included in the SANDSTORM series itself. 


 


If this project finds you unable to contribute in the monetary sense you can still contribute by sharing this request online with family and friends. Getting the word out about SANDSTORM is easy if you use the Indiegogo sharing tools that are available with this appeal. Any help you can give will most definitely contribute to the larger goal and it will also earn my eternal thanks.
If I do not reach the posted goal of $14,000, the funds that are raised will go first to purchasing the materials needed to complete this project and then to cover my day-to-day living expenses. Camera and projector upgrades can wait for another day.
Time and materials are the two essential elements I need to bring this series to life. My priorities will continue to remain with these fundamentals no matter the outcome of this campaign.
It has been a long time since I have been this excited about a potential new series and I am most confident that, with your help and my proven track-record, SANDSTORM will be an amazing series of paintings and an unqualified success for The Reach Gallery Museum and for myself.
Thank you.

story:
Our Story

(My name is Ginny Roberts, and I am a local artist and teacher in Central Alabama. I have had a shoe-string business-as in zero dollars to market or advertise-- for the last 3 years. I have not had the proper funding to grow my business and expand it so that it is more valuable to the community at large. This fundraiser will allow Ginn's Art to move to a larger location, to buy supplies, to reach more potential artists, to begin an after school high school art program, and community center art workshops for all ages. Ginn's Art provides paint parties, workshops, and classes, as well as volunteers her time working on community art projects- such as theatrical sets, and props for the local community theatre.


 

The Impact

This fundraiser would impact the community in which we live by providing children and adults with the opportunity to express themselves through art. It would provide a positive entertainment venue for children, teens, parents etc. It will also add to the educational experiences of our community as well as promote art and culture within our community. Additionally, it will add a viable business that could potentially expand throughout the state and possibly the country.

 

 What We Need & What You Get

 

In order to make this happen we need $16,000.

$3000.00 to lease an area for 6 months,

$2500 to purchase additional tables, chairs, sink, other fixtures, office equipment.

$3000.00 employee other artists for 6 months,

$1000 building and remodeling supplies and labor,

$3500 for art supplies,(paint, brushes, easels, canvas, etc.),

$3,000 for marketing and advertising. If we reach our goal and beyond we will be able to do great things. If we don't reach our goal we will work with what we have and try again. Some funding will come from what little the business has brought in to this point. Larger space, more supplies, more advertising, the business will explode into something awesome. For reaching out and helping Ginn's Art to expand, I would like to express my gratitude by giving you something in return. For our $20.00 contributers, Ginn's Art is giving away an autographed print of one of our featured artists. For our $100.00 contributers, Ginn's Art is giving away an autographed print, an original piece of artwork-signed by artist, and an original art print signed by Ginny Roberts. For our $1000.00 contributers, Ginn's Art is giving away an autograghed print, an original piece of artwork, an autographed print of Paul "Bear" Bryant, and an original piece of artwork painted and signed by Ginny Roberts.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word with others who you think would want to help this wonderful project get off the ground--Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn or any other social media you can think of. Thank you so much!!

story:
Our Story

The Mural Conservancy of Los Angeles (MCLA) is a 501-(c)3 non-profit organization founded in 1987 and is rooted in it's mission to retain mural arts as a part of Los Angeles' cultural legacy, by preserving, documenting, and protecting Los Angeles' culturally historic public mural arts.


We are currently working with conservators, art advocates, public agencies and the original muralist Kent Twitchell to restore "Jim Morphesis Monument" on the 101 Freeway. We are beginning the restoration process in November 2011 and need to raise $6,000 in funding for the completion of this project.


Impact of Murals in Los Angeles

 Los Angeles was known as one of the great mural capitals of the world at one time, boasting the production of thousands of murals by world renowned artists and members of Los Angeles diverse communities.  Today, Los Angeles visual culture is under serious threat as these massive monuments that once adorned the streets and freeways of this city with vibrant color and our cultural histories are now deteriorating under the weight of tagging, aggressive weather damage, and city-wide neglect. Running parallel to the ongoing physical degradation of these visual legacies are dramatic cuts in spending on the arts nationwide as well as the massive closure of community based cultural programs. In the face of this collective hardship, we are confronted with an ever increasing need for public visual arts to provide a source of creativity and inspiration to the people of Los Angeles. 


Benefits of Public Art Murals

- Help communities prosper and creates a sense of respect and civic pride.

- Business magnets.

- Attract tourism revenue.

- Students engaged in the arts perform better academically.


What is the money being used for?

We are trying to raise $6,000 to complete the restoration of the "Jim Morphesis Monument" Olympic Freeway Mural. All proceeds cover the expenses associated with the completion of the restoration process including equipment and supplies. As well the original muralist Kent Twitchell will play an active role donating his time in restoration and touch ups as needed.

Your contribution of any amount makes a critical impact in bringing this iconic mural back to it's original glory.


Other Ways You Can Help

Support this work by sharing this campaign with friends, family, co-workers and follow us on facebook and twitter to find how you can be involved.


facebook.com/muralconservancy

twitter.com/theMCLA

story:
Hi, 

I'm Sean Hennessey, an artist making kiln formed, illuminated glass relief sculpture. I create pieces inspired by the works of fellow humans. By stories and buildings and inventions. By science and myth and cities. I’m fascinated by the worlds we create and the manner in which we explain things. I gravitate toward materials of the built environment: wood, concrete, steel and most predominately glass. I make work to send to galleries, pieces that are meant to be part of larger series and exhibitions, experimental pieces, commissions, and public art. 

I've recently moved to Seattle with my wife Jess, and our son Atlas. It's been a longstanding dream of mine to live on the west coast. I love the vibe here, the ocean, the mountains. As much as I deeply love DC, Baltimore and the east coast, we're thrilled that we had the opportunity to make it possible to move across the country. 

 Before moving to the west coast, I was the co-director of Otis Street Arts Project, a Studio Center, Gallery and Arts incubator space in Washington, DC. It was a dream space, and my co-creator and co-director David Mordini and I had a beautifully supportive, active,  and creative community there. 

 I maintained my studio at Otis Street and had a kiln that had been passed down from studio to studio until it came to me when I got it from the Washington Glass School as they were upgrading. I owe my entire glass career to the directors there, Tim, Erwin, and Michael and it was an honor to own one of their kilns and having them right next door helped me through many creative and business challenges. 

 Here's the old kiln:

I'm a very productive artist and was able to create many beautiful glass castings from this kiln.  But it was old, rusty, cracking and was just not fit for travel across the country, nor did I have a place to ship it, or the money to ship it. Ultimately I decided to rehome this poor creature.  

We came to Seattle and started looking for a home to settle into and studio space. We finally found a place here in a great neighborhood in Seattle and it has a free standing garage that I will convert into a workspace. My excitement is immense and I'm deeply anxious to get back to the studio.

Behold my new studio!

 

The thing that I need most is a new kiln. 

I'm asking you to help contribute to this purchase.

 I've used many kilns, and have been searching for the perfect kiln for years. I've gotten lots of quotes, and estimates for custom built, and well, frankly, the type and size of kiln I want is shockingly expensive. 

My newest works are about 4'x2' and I want to be able to cast these in one piece. It puts my kiln need on the larger side, but anything smaller wouldn't work for the vision I have. 

Earlier last year, I met and taught at Gail Stouffer's Studio in Bulverde Texas. In addition to getting  hooked on Bullseye Glass, Gail introduced me to Jen-Ken Kilns,  which she sells through her business Kiln Frog.  These are a lighter weight, fusing style of kiln, with fiberboard walls instead of heavy insulating bricks. 

These kilns rock for the technique I use and I haven't found anything that was better suited.

Look how gorgeous it is:

With this new kiln, in my new space, I will be able to resume my glass sculpture practice, creating newer and larger scale works. I will also be able to host visiting artists, and work with community groups on public projects.  A new kiln allows me to continue my career in bigger and broader ways. 

Here are the specifics:

Budget

Kiln:  JenKen Profusion 52 -   $6,700

( This includes TAP Smart Controller and Solid State Relays)

https://kilnfrog.com/products/afg-profusion-fib...

 

Electrical Upgrades: $1500

( The garage has power, but it will need a heavy up and electrical panel)

 

Total: $8200

I am adding in a buffer for taxes, fees and permits and am seeking a total of $10,000 in funding.

I hope you find value in helping me achieve my goal by contributing to my effort and also by sharing this with others you think might be interested. For your contribution, I'm offering rewards of thanks, or original art, and of personal experiences. 

 

Thank you, 
Sean Hennessey
