Ultimately I decided to rehome this poor creature.  We came to Seattle and started looking for a home to settle into and studio space. We finally found a place here in a great neighborhood in Seattle and it has a free standing garage that I will convert into a workspace. My excitement is immense and I'm deeply anxious to get back to the studio.Behold my new studio! The thing that I need most is a new kiln. I'm asking you to help contribute to this purchase. I've used many kilns, and have been searching for the perfect kiln for years. I've gotten lots of quotes, and estimates for custom built, and well, frankly, the type and size of kiln I want is shockingly expensive. My newest works are about 4'x2' and I want to be able to cast these in one piece. It puts my kiln need on the larger side, but anything smaller wouldn't work for the vision I have. Earlier last year, I met and taught at Gail Stouffer's Studio in Bulverde Texas. In addition to getting  hooked on Bullseye Glass, Gail introduced me to Jen-Ken Kilns,  which she sells through her business Kiln Frog.  These are a lighter weight, fusing style of kiln, with fiberboard walls instead of heavy insulating bricks. These kilns rock for the technique I use and I haven't found anything that was better suited.Look how gorgeous it is:With this new kiln, in my new space, I will be able to resume my glass sculpture practice, creating newer and larger scale works. I will also be able to host visiting artists, and work with community groups on public projects.  A new kiln allows me to continue my career in bigger and broader ways. Here are the specifics:BudgetKiln:  JenKen Profusion 52 -   $6,700( This includes TAP Smart Controller and Solid State Relays)https://kilnfrog.com/products/afg-profusion-fib... Electrical Upgrades: $1500( The garage has power, but it will need a heavy up and electrical panel) Total: $8200I am adding in a buffer for taxes, fees and permits and am seeking a total of $10,000 in funding.I hope you find value in helping me achieve my goal by contributing to my effort and also by sharing this with others you think might be interested. For your contribution, I'm offering rewards of thanks, or original art, and of personal experiences.  Thank you, Sean Hennessey

story:
Update


A huge thank you to everyone who contributed and helped spread the word. We hit our goal, the t-shirts are in and the posters are arriving soon. We also have our web site up so head over to shopflyoverpress.com today.

 

Update

If the campaign hits $2500, the Crossroads of America print will be released at the launch.  Inspired by Indiana's nickname resulting from the large amount of interstates crisscrossing the state, the poster depicts the state on a modified interstate sign.

Short Summary

To quote Don Draper, "Well, as I said before, I'm from the Midwest. We were taught that it's not polite to talk about yourself."  That's how we were taught to grow up in the Midwest, to be humble and not to brag.  But there's a problem in that.  It means we are often overlooked by the rest of the country.  They don't talk about us and we are too humble to talk about us and thus we are ignored.  Maybe it's time we started talking about ourselves.

That is why Flyover Press was born.  To help show our pride in being from the states others would rather just flyover.  To show them what they are missing.  To convince them they may just want to take in the heartland from the ground and not just the air.  To project our identity to the rest of the country.  To be the voice that we are often too humble to use.

Flyover Press creates letterpress posters inspired by the states, the regions, the culture, the heritage and the people of the Midwest.  Each 13" x 20" poster will be pressed in limited runs using the traditional method onto 110lb. letterpress paper.  The pressing itself is done in Chicago using handset type and linoleum cuts and good old-fashioned Midwestern hard work.  Midwestern letterpress posters made in the Midwest by Midwesterners.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $2000 to fund the first three prints, koozies, t-shirts and to set up an ecommerce web site.  Any funding above the goal will go towards creating additional prints for additional states. Want your state to get a print right away? Make sure we don't just meet our goal but exceed it.

So what do you get for helping Flyover Press out?  Besides the satisfaction of helping bolster Midwestern pride and supporting made in the USA values, you'll receive a variety of perks depending on your contribution level.

  • All contributors will receive a personal thank you note and a shout out on Facebook and Twitter and will also receive notice of new prints before everyone else and access to special Founder's Sales and Promotions.
  • All contributions of $5 or more will receive a Flyover Press koozie
  • Contributions of $25 will receive a Flyover Press t-shirt
  • Contributions of $30 or more will receive a choice of one print or a credit for a future print.  The prints will retail for $35 so we want to thank the people who helped us get a start (you all) with a special price.
  • Additional prints or credits can be earned in increments of $30 contributions ($60 = 2, $90 = 3, etc.)
  • Contributions of $55 will receive a choice of one print or a credit for a future print, a t-shirt and a koozie.
  • Really feeling generous?  Contributions of $500 or more will receive the opportunity to work with Flyover Press to design a special print.  You will receive this print and your choice of an additional three, plus two t-shirts, two koozies and the print will be available for the entire world to purchase.  Pretty cool, huh?

Please note that the posters have not been printed yet (that's why I'm raising money) and the final product may vary slightly in terms of font and color.

Four Star Flag Print - A letterpress take on Chicago's iconic flag.

Ohio Print - Inspired by an Ohio license plate, something you won't see when flying over

HOMES Print - Inspired by the acronym for learning our Great Lakes

Flyover Press Koozie - Logo with Midwest outline printed on a Made in the USA koozie

The Flyover Press T-Shirt - Screenprinted on soft ringspun combed cotton t-shirts made in the USA.  Script on the back reads "Midwest, The Land I Love The Best"

The Impact

Your contribution will go a long way towards building Midwestern pride.  You'll be helping a Midwestern company build a brand we can all be proud of while supporting American-made goods and American jobs.  A succesful campaign will establish a sound base to continue expanding into new states and potentially new products for displaying Midwestern pride.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please spread the word to anyone you know who loves the Midwest and let them know how they can help support the campaign.
  • Make sure to use the Indiegogo share tools to alert your friends and family to this campaign.

Thank you from the Midwest, the land we love the best.

For a look at how letterpress prints are made, please view the following video:

Jack Daniel's Does Letterpress

story:
The Circle Bridge 

Moviehouse's The Circle Bridge is a new site-specific video performance that combines live choreography and large-scale animation of Nathan Punwar to tell a story of interconnectivity, travel and history. 

Audience members follow their own distinct narrative as they walk the span of the 2810 foot *Pulaski Bridge that connects Greenpoint, Brooklyn with Long Island City, Queens across the Newtown Creek. 

Along their walk, they encounter animations/projections by Nathan Punwar and two unique dance performances by Blue Muse Dance that each tell a distinct part of the tale. Each element is integrally designed to give each viewer a unique all-encompassing visual, audio and physical experience.

The Circle Bridge is structured by six overlapping stories that are grounded in the history of the bridge, the neighborhoods that surround it and the communities that live and work there. The audience meets six distinct characters and they traverse time and space in interconnected loops. Projected photographs morph into large animations on warehouses and come to life as dancers on the bridge itself. 

  • Outreach program:                                                                                                    We are in the process of writing a curriculum to be taught to school children in the area to create their own Circle Bridge.

*The Pulaski Bridge in New York City connects Long Island City in Queens to Greenpoint in Brooklyn over Newtown Creek. It was named after Polish military commander and American Revolutionary War fighter Kazimierz Pułaski (Casimir Pulaski) because of the large Polish-American population in Greenpoint.  It connects 11th Street in Queens to McGuinness Boulevard (formerly Oakland Street) in Brooklyn.

The Pulaski Bridge opened to traffic on September 10, 1954. It served as a replacement for the nearby Vernon Avenue Bridge, which had linked Vernon Avenue in Long Island City with Manhattan Avenue in Greenpoint.

Designed by Frederick Zurmuhlen, the Pulaski Bridge is a bascule bridge, a type of drawbridge. It carries six lanes of traffic and a pedestrian sidewalk over the water, Long Island Rail Road tracks, and the entrance to the Queens-Midtown Tunnel. The pedestrian sidewalk is on the west or downstream side of the bridge, which has good views of the industrial areas surrounding Newtown Creek, the skyline of Manhattan, and of a number of other bridges, including the Williamsburg Bridge, the Queensboro Bridge, and the Kosciuszko Bridge. The bridge was reconstructed between 1991 and 1994.

From Left/Top: BMD Dance Artists: Hazuki Homma (Associate Dir.), Femi Olagoke, Malin Barr, Megan Nordle, Robin Johnson and Matthew Roberts. 

We'd appreciate if you could show your love & support.

Yes!!

WE have an incredible amount of passion for this project. Our mission now is to bring this exciting work to YOU! 

  • Please check out our Gallery of pictures at Pulaski Bridge & Animation on this site.
  • You'd like to know who's involved in this project?  

Please visit here:

http://www.bluemusedance.org/company

Stay tuned for more pictures, videos and stories.

Thank you so much for your time & support!!


Moviehouse

Moviehouse is an interactive video project led by director Chris Henderson that creates site-specific work in alternative locations. Our main purpose is to connect audiences and artists with impactful and relevant experiences that push video out of two-dimensional space. 

Creative Team:

Director: Chris Henderson/Moviehouse
Choreography: Mayuna Shimizu/Blue Muse Dance
Animation: Nathan Punwar
Performers: Hazuzi Homma, Matthew Roberts, Femi Olagoke, Malin Barr, Robin Johnson & Megan Nordle

Producer: Felicia A. Swoope/Gendarc Dance NYC
Sponsorship: Broadway Stages


GENDARC DANCE NYC

Felicia A. Swoope received her B.A. in English from Dartmouth College and her M.F.A. in Dance from TischSchool of the Arts at New YorkUniversity. She was the Founding Curator of E-Moves, the emerging choreographers’ showcase at Aaron Davis Hall (now Harlemstage). She has performed with various modern dance companies.  She was a teaching artist for Battery Dance Company for three years and Alvin Ailey’s Arts-In-Education Program (AileyKids) for seven years and served as the first Camp Director for AileyCamp Newark (one of 10 Alvin Ailey summer camps across the country for at-risk youth). As the founder of GENDARC Dance NYC, she produces showcases for choreographers, hosts workshops for pre-professional and professional dancers. She now has her own Dance Arts-In-Education program in the NYC public schools. (www.gendarcdancenyc.com)


Preview!!

Blue Muse Dance performed a preview of The Circle Bridge as a part of Dixon Place presents International Women Artists' Salon's 
Salon Lounge. 

Date: Monday, August 26th

Time: 7:30PM

http://www.dixonplace.org/html/lounge.html

-- featuring

Hiromi Abe: Brazilian Music

Barbara Clark : Poetry

Annie Yan : Video Piece

Jenny Green: Theatrical Reading 

Blue Muse Dance: Preview of The Circle Bridge project 

Where: Dixon Place 
161A Chrystie Street, New York, NY 10002
(btwn Delancey and Rivington, West side of Chrystie Street)
Closest trains: J, M, F, M B, D 
(Bowery, Essex/Delancey, 2nd Ave, Grand St.)
212.219.0736

International Woman Artist's salon

Mayuna Shimizu/Blue Muse Dance is a memeber/co-curator of International Woman Artist's Salon.

This Salon, founded by curator, Heidi Russell, is a cross-disciplinary, cross-cultural organization of women making art in the world today. Our aim is to bring art by women to the fore of the art world and local communities through exhibitions and events, exchanges, regular salon style gatherings and an online forum for members and interested parties.

Our shared vision is to create a community of individuals and organizations with the resources and passion to gain critical visibility in the art world for women artists of all backgrounds and stages of career. Every member helps achieve our goal of building connections among artists, arts organizations, and the public. With your participation, there are unlimited possibilities!

For more: http://womenartsalon.blogspot.com

story:
Pink is the new black!

It's time for some new shirts, featuring your favorite webcomic queers! 

Unfortunately, there are times when nudity is frowned upon. For those rare and unfair times, Capitol Hillbillies shirts are the answer. Show off your Hillbilly pride with one of these two shirts:

Love good head? One shirt's got the four main hillbillies from the non-existent neck up. 

Wanna know you know how to handle a big sword? Clark's got ya covered in his Duel-Handed Weapon shirt. 

Please help us make a fashion statement: sodomy is funny. 

Thanks for your donations!

story:
Folk Architecture Monument

Is a unique project by the artist Tomáš Džadoň. Its first version dates back to 2006, and gradually the idea of a work of art to be set up in a public space in Košice took shape. The Folk Architecture Monument consists of three "classic" log cottages situated on the roof of a "classic" prefabricated housing block on one of the largest housing estates in Košice. This iconic artistic gesture represents for the author a deeper reality, in which many inhabitants of Košice and elsewhere have grown up and lived. Let us not forget that around half the inhabitants of Slovakia live in prefabricated housing blocks. The project is an opportunity and an inspiration for a new perception of one's own history, of which housing estate architecture is an intrinsic part. The Folk Architecture Monument has the potential to be a unique type of monument. It is not a monument to a historic person, event or memory. It involves the present we have lived through, taken symbolically: the housing block is us. The inhabitants of the Monument will become active co-artists in the project. It is a highly attractive work of art for the public at large, too, not only for a circle of interested professionals. Its monumental size and installation outside the over-exposed historic centre of Košice give it a human, citizen's and public aspect.

 

Tomáš Džadoň(1981),works and lives

Slovak visual artist, graduate of the Academy of Fine Arts in Prague, doctoral student at the Academy of Fine Arts and Design in Bratislava, winner of the Essl Award 2007, finalist of the Jindřich Chalupecký Award 2009, the Oskár Čepan Award 2012, laureate of the Young Artist Award 2012 of the Tatra Banka Foundation.

story:
Reason For Campaign:

 Not to long ago, I was financially comfortable and had what I needed to live my dream. I had an art studio, a decent size work station for my large, (4ft - 8ft), paintings, collages and frames, and, plenty of storage. I was ready to take the next step and invest in a gallery until someone, who was a big part of my life, did the unthinkable causing me to lose everything... I've had to start from scratch all over again.

 Since then, my space has been limited so I'm forced to work outside where I have to worry about the bugs getting into my paint, the rain, wind, temperature, etc... Most of my time is wasted now trying to figure out where I can paint, what day is best based on the weather, finding room to create my large paintings, room to create my collages, room to create my frames, where to store it all, as well as marketing it. My art is beautiful, unique and forever changing with all the creativity I have to offer. A few pieces are currently displayed at a couple of different locations, (the most recent being Naghi's in the French Quarter in NOLA), as well as online. Although I'm appreciative for any opportunities anyone gives me, 90% of my work sits in storage because its so large and most places only allow a couple of pieces to be displayed at a time. 

 Ultimately, I need a gallery that has plenty of room in back for a studio/work station and storage, and, plenty of wall space in front where my work can be proudly displayed and enjoyed by many. I'm hoping to give other artists the same opportunity by sharing my space with them.

 I'm only asking for help with the start up costs. If I don't raise enough to meet my goal, the money will be saved until I do. Any amount contributed will be greatly appreciated! Even if you don't donate, I hope you still check out my websites as I enjoy sharing my gift to others :-)

Please visit my Facebook page: www.facebook.com/artbymichelelyn, (where most of my work is displayed), or, my website: www.artbymichelelyn.com ,(currently under construction). There's also a few samples posted on top of this page under the "Gallery" tab, and, I've attached my 2012 CD for viewing.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my page, -Michele Lyn 

About the Artist:

￼ Michele is a self-taught Artist from Iowa. As a child, she would sit in her room while trying to draw pictures or objects she saw to perfection. Sometimes, she'd even sit in the kitchen and create sculptures out of aluminum foil while her Mother cooked, or, she'd create designs or sculptures out of garbage and give them as gifts to her friends and teachers, (lucky them- HA!). For her, it was like playing in the park, playing sports, etc... she assumed it was something all kids did. In grade school, whenever they had an art project to do, Michele usually got asked to make an extra one for the kids that weren't there- she never thought anything of it. It wasn't until high school that she realized it was an actual talent.

 Years later, Michele purchased an abundant amount of miscellaneous art supplies and had a studio where she tried a little bit of everything until she found her niche. She even took a couple of classes at Drake University to see if there was anything she might learn that she hadn't taught herself. Michele soon discovered that abstracts and color were her strongest attributes. She has been selling art privately for over 15 years and started selling online in 2005 through various websites.

 Michele uses Acrylic paint for most of her paintings and prefers to use pastels, colored pencil, chalk, charcoal or watercolor paint for more detailed work. Her art is a reflection of her personality. It’s spontaneous, colorful, energetic, mysterious and compassionate. She's always wanting & willing to try new things in life to prevent boredom while also capturing precious moments on film and embracing them on canvas, wood or paper. This is why you’ll usually see a variety in her work along with being able to captivate a diverse type of audience. Color is her strongest attribute along with simplistic, contemporary or modern type art. You’ll find most of Michele's abstracts quite versatile. They can either be hung vertically or horizontally. Whenever she starts painting or drawing an idea that she has, the finished product usually ends up being something entirely different creating a pleasant surprise in the end.

A B S T R A C T S:

"Breaking Down The Wall"

“My abstracts portray me the best. They’re a therapeutic way for me to release a lifetime of bottled up energy and emotions that have been trapped inside. I’m able to freely express myself without the fear of being judged or criticized while showing my adventurous and ambitious side at the same time. My abstracts also reflect the abnormally warped speeds my mind travels at forcing me to try and keep up with the thought process in my head. Therefore, once I start painting, I work at a very fast pace and rarely stop until it’s finished.”

C O L L A G E S:

"The Rebel In Me"

“This series shows my rebellious side! I spend countless hours creating numerous, amazing paintings on canvas, only to ruin them by courageously cutting them up and strategically placing them creating one giant masterpiece. This also creates a fascinating display of multiple, individual paintings, that will grab your attention and keep you from looking away. Sometimes you’ll see different materials incorporated into my work.”

S I L O U E T T E S:

“Open Up Your Inner Passion”

Quite simply, these display my more sensitive, caring & compassionate side. I created these in a way so when you look at them, they’ll lure in your eyes, and, relax your mind allowing you to embrace the beautiful moment tastefully.
story_txt:
Reason For Campaign:
 Not to long ago, I was financially comfortable and had what I needed to live my dream. I had an art studio, a decent size work station for my large, (4ft - 8ft), paintings, collages and frames, and, plenty of storage. I was ready to take the next step and invest in a gallery until someone, who was a big part of my life, did the unthinkable causing me to lose everything... I've had to start from scratch all over again.
 Since then, my space has been limited so I'm forced to work outside where I have to worry about the bugs getting into my paint, the rain, wind, temperature, etc... Most of my time is wasted now trying to figure out where I can paint, what day is best based on the weather, finding room to create my large paintings, room to create my collages, room to create my frames, where to store it all, as well as marketing it. My art is beautiful, unique and forever changing with all the creativity I have to offer. A few pieces are currently displayed at a couple of different locations, (the most recent being Naghi's in the French Quarter in NOLA), as well as online. Although I'm appreciative for any opportunities anyone gives me, 90% of my work sits in storage because its so large and most places only allow a couple of pieces to be displayed at a time. 
 Ultimately, I need a gallery that has plenty of room in back for a studio/work station and storage, and, plenty of wall space in front where my work can be proudly displayed and enjoyed by many. I'm hoping to give other artists the same opportunity by sharing my space with them.
 I'm only asking for help with the start up costs. If I don't raise enough to meet my goal, the money will be saved until I do. Any amount contributed will be greatly appreciated! Even if you don't donate, I hope you still check out my websites as I enjoy sharing my gift to others :-)
Please visit my Facebook page: www.facebook.com/artbymichelelyn, (where most of my work is displayed), or, my website: www.artbymichelelyn.com ,(currently under construction). There's also a few samples posted on top of this page under the "Gallery" tab, and, I've attached my 2012 CD for viewing.
Thanks for taking the time to visit my page, -Michele Lyn 
About the Artist:
￼ Michele is a self-taught Artist from Iowa. As a child, she would sit in her room while trying to draw pictures or objects she saw to perfection. Sometimes, she'd even sit in the kitchen and create sculptures out of aluminum foil while her Mother cooked, or, she'd create designs or sculptures out of garbage and give them as gifts to her friends and teachers, (lucky them- HA!). For her, it was like playing in the park, playing sports, etc... she assumed it was something all kids did. In grade school, whenever they had an art project to do, Michele usually got asked to make an extra one for the kids that weren't there- she never thought anything of it. It wasn't until high school that she realized it was an actual talent.
 Years later, Michele purchased an abundant amount of miscellaneous art supplies and had a studio where she tried a little bit of everything until she found her niche. She even took a couple of classes at Drake University to see if there was anything she might learn that she hadn't taught herself. Michele soon discovered that abstracts and color were her strongest attributes. She has been selling art privately for over 15 years and started selling online in 2005 through various websites.

Her art is a reflection of her personality. It’s spontaneous, colorful, energetic, mysterious and compassionate. She's always wanting & willing to try new things in life to prevent boredom while also capturing precious moments on film and embracing them on canvas, wood or paper. This is why you’ll usually see a variety in her work along with being able to captivate a diverse type of audience. story:
Greetings to all,

 

I am writing because our beloved Invictus Animus is about to have a birthday, and I want you to help make it a spectacular one!

Now... we all know that Invictus is a special person.  He is a man of many talents- writer, actor, leader, innovator. But, many of us first met Invictus because of his fantastic fashion sense and skill as a costum designer.  So, I was hoping that we could come together and for his birthday give Invictus enough funds to create a few more costumes that he has in mind, but doesn't currenlty have the funds to execute.  I know he plans to make a new and much more fabulous set of wings, in addition to refitting tsome of the older costumes and perhaps purchasing a steampunk style suit.  I would love to see these dreams come true for him and you can help that happen.

So, if you feel lead, please contribute.  The size of the donation does not matter, it is the thought that counts.

 

Help me give Invictus a birthday he will not forget.

 

All Love,

Seppi
(Stephanie Rogers)

story:
My name is Paul Komoda and I'm an artist and sculptor. The life of an artist can be immensely rewarding as well as very challenging. Currently my situation is exceedingly challenging!

So I've set up this campaign and I'm offering rare prints, jewelry, sculpture castings, original drawings and sketches, as well as a few surprises.

The money will help me get through this difficult period and allow me to complete some projects, as well as create more art.

Thank you so much for your help!


Perks

Mystery Brain Spew sketches - I will do an original one-of-a-kind ink sketch on bristol paper just for you!







Nano Cthulhloids - Ink on paper. Double sided. Signed.


DOOM Designs - Hastur and various figure design sketches for "The Doom That Came to Atlantic City"  Pencil & watercolor on 11 x 14 bristol.



Tlamixec Battlelord - design for Wizards of the Coast's Dreamblade"  Pencil on 11 x 14 bristol. 


Organ Golem Dreamblade - design for Wizards of the Coast's Dreamblade" Pencil on 11 x 14 bristol. 


DOOM Cthulhu Designs - Miniature figure designs for "The Doom That Came to Atlantic City" Pencil on  11 x 14 bristol.


Doublivore - Sharpie and colored pencil drawing 11x 8 1/2. 


Ghost Rider



Fuck You Too - Double-sided sketchbook page. Pen drawing 12 x 9.


Prince of Blades - figure design for Wizards of the Coast's Dreamblade. Pencil on 14x11 bristol.





Elder God - Pen & ink sketchbook excerpt.


The Thing concept art - Pen & ink. 2011 "The Thing" prequel production designs.


"The Thing" early design art - Pencil on paper. Signed 2011 "The Thing" early design art. 



Fluffy Variations - Original ink drawing with several permutations of my character, Fluffy. Signed.


Fluffy Permutations - Original ink sketches of various Fluffy's. Signed.


Atomic Mutant Fluffy - Original sharpie drawing of the Atomic Mutant Fluffy on one side, and Mutant Housefly Fluffy on the back. Double sided. Signed.

story:
the short of it:

 welcome to the crowdfunding campaign for beeluxe’s trek-inspired pride pin! every trekkie deserves to be included in trek merch, but that doesn’t mean they always are. my goal is to make things for the community, by the community, starting with this pride pin.

what we need to raise and why:

the up front cost of the enamel pins is $200USD/$250CAD (indiegogo doesn't allow goals under $500, but our goal is $250). this includes:

  • blank creation and mold casting of the design
  • production of an initial batch zinc-alloy, gold plated pins with two posts each
  • rubber pin backs
  • shipping to canada for inspection and packaging

what you’ll get:

i plan to price each pin at $15CAD/$12USD on my site. by becoming an initial backer, you’ll get (tier perks vary):

  • a discounted pin rate of $10USD/pin
  • a matching 2 inch trek pride sticker with metallic gold foil finish
  • a matching 2 inch trek pride magnet

challenges:

the biggest challenge is the time table. pins take anywhere from 4-6 weeks to make and ship. i do anticipate them arriving sooner, as my manufacturer is very quick with their turnaround. however, i would be remiss if i didn’t lay out that time frame just in case. we are funding this in the middle of a panini.

this project will go forward with whatever funding we get. i don’t want to promise something and not deliver. this campaign is to keep me from going into debt to make this happen!

story:
Bref résumé

Depuis sa création en 2016, Des livre et des réfugié-e-s a publié deux recueils. Grâce à la collaboration d'auteur-e-s acharné-e-s et de librairies indépendantes, nous avons réussi à vendre plusieurs centaines de ces recueils. Grâce au travail ininterrompu de l'organisme, de la générosité des librairies, de l'attention médiatique que le projet a suscité, mais surtout grâce à toutes celles et tous ceux qui ont la cause à cœur, nous avons réussi à venir en aide à plusieurs familles réfugiées dans le besoin. 

 Ce dont nous avons besoin et ce que vous obtenez

  •  Élargir nos horizons et poursuivre la mission de notre organisme dans le but d'aider le plus de familles possible.

 

  •  Pour toute contribution de 5 $ nous vous enverrons une copie électronique du recueil de poésie « Les âmes crépusculaires ».
  • Pour toute contribution de 15 $ nous vous enverrons une copie dédicacée du recueil de poésie « Les âmes crépusculaires »
  • Pour toute contribution de 25$ nous vous enverrons une copie dédicacée de l'édition limitée des « Confessions d'un enfant du XXIe siècle ».
  • Pour toute contribution de 100$ et plus nous vous écrirons soit un poème ou une histoire personnalisé et inédit-e + une copie du recueil « Des mots pour les réfugié-e-s » qui sera disponible à l'automne 2018. 

 L'impact

  • En plus de contribuer à l'intégration scolaire et sociale d'enfants réfugiés dans la société québécoise notre organisme encourage la culture québécoises avec ses publications. 
  • Nous faisons découvrir de nouveaux talents en littérature.

 

DL&DR dans les médias reportages vidéo :  

 - Ici Radio-Canada : https://ici.radio-canada.ca/nouvelle/1004320/de...  

 - TVA Nouvelles : http://www.tvanouvelles.ca/2016/02/12/un-ex-ref...  

 

 Le Nouvelliste

« Pour Adis Simidzija, l'important c'est de donner sans rien attendre en retour, parce que l'action est plus importante que le résultat.

«Le résultat ne sera jamais satisfaisant, puisqu'il va toujours y avoir des enfants qui souffrent.»

C'est dans cet esprit qu'il a fondé «Des livres et des réfugié-e-s», un organisme qui vient en aide aux nouveaux arrivants et facilite leur intégration dans la société québécoise.

Depuis janvier 2016, il s'applique à récolter des fonds pour aider matériellement et offrir du soutien à des jeunes qui ont été déracinés et qui tentent de se refaire une vie dans un nouvel environnement. 

Né en Bosnie-Herzégovine, le jeune Adis a grandi dans un pays déchiré par la guerre. Le déracinement, il connaît. À l'aube de ses 10 ans, sa mère a quitté son pays natal, où son père avait été tué, pour trouver refuge, avec ses deux fils, au Québec. »

Source : https://www.lenouvelliste.ca/actualites/tete-da...

story:
***Update 8/7/13

- We have added a bunch of new art for the final count down. New canvas's from Globe, Sonz, and we just got a big shipment of stickers and accessories from THE SEVENTH LETTER.   Order your Sticker Packs we have lots of stickers from around the country.     ** LAST CHANCE**

***Update 25/6/13

- We've added a one of a kind print from the artist, Mediah. Claim this one of a kind 13" x 19" print for only $100!

- Added some $15 mixed cap bags, courtesy of the good people over at Joe Huffer paint shop!

***Update 19/6/13

- Just added another canvas from the artist, Motel. Claim this one of a kind 18" x 24" canvas for only $200!

***Update 18/6/13

- Just added a great canvas from the artist, Smug. Claim this one of a kind 3' x 3' "G" canvas for only $250!

***Update 12/6/13

- We just added a couple dope prints from the amazing artist, Peru! $20 each, limit of 10

- Block By Block packs - 1x drip stick, 1x squeezer and 1x mop. $30, limit of 10

Also, a big thanks to every that has donated so far! If you made a sizable donation, we will be hooking you up with something special too!

 

Sunday June 9th 2013. Our friend, Globe One, GH KAS, was the victim of unfortunate circumstances when his studio was burnt down due to an electric fire.

Thankfully his wife and daughter are safe and unharmed, but the freak accident has left them out of home and affected his ability to earn a living. We know many of you viewing this page are artists yourselves, so please imagine loosing your body of work and all of your supplies. We are reaching out to our friends, family and people of the graffiti community and supports of Toronto’s art scene to help out by making a donation. Anything you can contribute to the cause will be greatly appreciated.

Over the next few weeks we will be adding rewards for various donation amounts, although due to the nature of the incident, we are all unprepared. We will be adding sticker packs, a limited original t-shirt, markers, original art and more.

We would just like to thank you all in advance for your support in friends time of need.

story:
Our Mission:

Essubi Arts' mission is to teach multi-disciplinary art lessons that foster imagination, hope and healing to Ugandan children living with orphan hearts. Essubi means Hope.

Essubi Arts will be returning, for the third time, to work with New Hope Uganda, a children’s center whose mission is to ‘bring the Fatherhood of God to the Fatherless’, from June 23 through July 10th, 2013. Our vision is to provide continued art creation opportunities, in a variety of mediums to the children living at New Hope Uganda who have very limited access and resources in these areas. It is our desire is to equip children with orphan hearts to explore the world creatively so they may open the windows of imagination, curiosity, and self-expression and find new ways to connect with their Creator.

What We Do:

We help children explore, craft, and share their stories through art in a variety of mediums. We will be working closely with the staff of New Hope Uganda, to assist in the development of ‘ArtCare’. The idea of ‘ArtCare’ is to use art as a tool to reveal and heal what’s in the heart. An art project can be a safe place where a child could express something that happened in their past, or something that is currently going on in their heart, without necessarily having to use words. Most of the children we will work with are former abductees, forced to be child soldiers for Joseph Kony and his rebel group, the LRA. We will first lead a training session for the staff in how to use ArtCare as a way to care more deeply for each other and for the children. How to discuss the art projects with the children, to foster relationships with openness and trust, to present challenges and problems, to reach to the roots and open understanding, and to bring the light of Christ to the deep, dark, wounded places of the heart, through his love in relationship.

Who We Are:

Essubi Arts was founded by Rachael Harrington, Christopher Davis and Leslie Flynt in 2010.

This year, a team of 5 multi-disciplinary artists (actors, visual artists, musicians, writers, filmmaker) from Brooklyn, NY, will be joining forces to travel to New Hope Uganda from June 23rd - July 10th.

The Team: Leslie Flynt, Livia Beasley, Robin Hilkey, Gillian Sollenberger, and Virginia Young. Leslie will be staying on for 4 months to work with New Hope Uganda.

How You Can Help:

We are truly thankful for this opportunity to serve, and ask that you consider joining us in ministry! We are seeking your prayers and support for this mission trip. If you would like to give financially, please note that Essubi Arts is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Essubi Arts must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Thank You!

 

Learn More:

http://essubiarts.wix.com/hope

Essubi Arts' mission is to teach multi-disciplinary art lessons that foster imagination, hope and healing to Ugandan children living with orphan hearts. Essubi means Hope.
Essubi Arts will be returning, for the third time, to work with New Hope Uganda, a children’s center whose mission is to ‘bring the Fatherhood of God to the Fatherless’, from June 23 through July 10th, 2013. Our vision is to provide continued art creation opportunities, in a variety of mediums to the children living at New Hope Uganda who have very limited access and resources in these areas. It is our desire is to equip children with orphan hearts to explore the world creatively so they may open the windows of imagination, curiosity, and self-expression and find new ways to connect with their Creator.
What We Do:
We help children explore, craft, and share their stories through art in a variety of mediums. We will be working closely with the staff of New Hope Uganda, to assist in the development of ‘ArtCare’. The idea of ‘ArtCare’ is to use art as a tool to reveal and heal what’s in the heart. An art project can be a safe place where a child could express something that happened in their past, or something that is currently going on in their heart, without necessarily having to use words. Most of the children we will work with are former abductees, forced to be child soldiers for Joseph Kony and his rebel group, the LRA. We will first lead a training session for the staff in how to use ArtCare as a way to care more deeply for each other and for the children. How to discuss the art projects with the children, to foster relationships with openness and trust, to present challenges and problems, to reach to the roots and open understanding, and to bring the light of Christ to the deep, dark, wounded places of the heart, through his love in relationship.
Who We Are:
Essubi Arts was founded by Rachael Harrington, Christopher Davis and Leslie Flynt in 2010.
This year, a team of 5 multi-disciplinary artists (actors, visual artists, musicians, writers, filmmaker) from Brooklyn, NY, will be joining forces to travel to New Hope Uganda from June 23rd - July 10th.
The Team: Leslie Flynt, Livia Beasley, Robin Hilkey, Gillian Sollenberger, and Virginia Young. Leslie will be staying on for 4 months to work with New Hope Uganda.
How You Can Help:
We are truly thankful for this opportunity to serve, and ask that you consider joining us in ministry! We are seeking your prayers and support for this mission trip. If you would like to give financially, please note that Essubi Arts is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Essubi Arts must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.
Thank You!
 
Learn More:
http://essubiarts.wix.com/hope

story:
Summary

1 – About the creator of the project Dans’Artes

2- What is about?

3-The magnitude of your contribution

4 – What we need?

5 – The Impact

1 - My name is Maria Helena Pinto I’m a choreographer, dancer, dance teacher, a contemporary dance field researcher in Mozambique and an artistic/cultural shows and events producer. I’m doing my PhD. Degree in Arts Technology Science and Aesthetics, Theatre/Dance option at the University of Paris 8. I’m a co-founder of the Isarc Arts and Culture University in Mozambique. I was one of the chief choreographers of Companhia Nacional de Canto e Dança de Moçambique (National Singing and Dance Company of Mozambique) from 1995 to 2009 and Artistic Director in 2004. I was the jury chair of the FUNDAC Prize, Dance-Theatre category in Mozambique in 2006 and 2009. I’m the founder of FIDC project, first International Contemporary Dance Festival in Mozambique and was its general coordinator in 2006. I’m also the founder and President of the Choreographic Research Center Association in Maputo. And I’m the founder of the Dans’Artes architectonic construction project to be implanted in Djonasse community, in Matola-Rio Maputo-Mozambique.

2 – What is about?

Construction of a physical space (artistic village), called Dans’Artes.

www.dansartes.com

 

  • Therefore, it should be noted that the construction and complete equipping of premises of this arts and culture space Dans’Artes, shall depend on financial means that we have  and financial support that we may get from different institutions, funding, donations and all typo of means that we need for the construction of this place of dreams, life, image, sensations, dance art, photography, cinema; culture, rhythms, traditional or contemporary from which the history of people shall reflect in the meeting and crossing with the external world. That way we are doing different types of operations like cultural and artistic activities, presentation of the project to different audience’s etc. to find partners’ and here we need contributors who can help as in funds to continue to build our Theater inside the village.      

  3 – The magnitude of your contribution

 The magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve is:

  • This artistic village intends to bring infrastructures to accommodate artistic-pedagogic training activities, art and culture diffusion (Crafts and Paintings exhibitions, photographic exhibitions, different artistic expressions festivals, musical concerts, dance shows, theater, circus, edition of literary writings, etc).
  • Dans’Artes aims at contributing and steering with conservation and exhibition of cultural and artistic assets, contemporary artistic creations, etc.
  • At Dans’Artes a flow of artistic cultural interchanges shall emerge at local, regional and international level, that shall mean a support for the global development of the central areas of its development, bringing benefits not only for Mozambique, but also for the different countries of the continent and of the world.
  • This is the crossing place of artists, cultural players, cultural operators, professionals, amateurs and public of different universes and origins.
  • This artistic village that is being implanted within Djonasse community aims at interacting with local natives enabling the establishment of new public for national and international arts and culture.
  • Dans’Artes shall create new jobs, carry out training in different fields consequently contributing for the social and economic development within this community.

4 - What We Need?

  • For the next step to build the Theater of the Artistic Village Dans’Artes we need is 85 071,63. This amount going to invest to achieve one of the part of the theater which is to finish the walls, to cover the Theater, to electrify and to put make the system of plumber.  In one way with this part of the building finished we can do some of the activities inside and get ready to help people, artists, community and more.  
  • Dans’Artes is a project that has an approach to the lack of spaces for development artistic-cultural activities and for the accommodation of youth and artists in general, its implication on the individual’s training and educational activities.
  • For durability and autonomy of artistic-cultural institutions and  projects it is essential that:
  • There is a physical space where different activities can developed at local level. Therefore, we see the need to find partners that may assist in making it become true in Mozambique. There is the need to build the capacity of local institutions in a diversity of means in order to make it possible to achieve the objectives intended locally.
  • In that perspective, each local artistic-cultural specialty must be sustainable, thereby creating an institutional autonomy that shall allow in medium and long term for their material, logistic and financial dependence. This shall open doors for the projects sustainable and long lasting development, with a stronger opening for national and international cooperation.

5 - The Impact

In Helping in this campaign with your contribution you will make a difference:

Dans’Artes will be the most important alternative to the current theatre halls and a more value, given the scarcity of spaces for development artistic-cultural activities at the level of the surrounding zones of Maputo city, in particular and the accommodation of youth and artists in general. Dans’Artes visualizes itself under five transversal development points of which development of Community, Arts, Culture, Tourism and Economy.

You can make your contribution but you also can make know this for those who you know can contribute to make this dream become truth. You will be also to come in Mozambique whenever you want to see what you did for our Dream and the life’s you contribute to chance here. We believe in this dream and waiting that you will be part of it.

Each contribution count so:

WE THANK YOU ALL FOR ALL CONTRIBUTION YOU CAN GIVE FOR THIS DREAM.

Maria Helena Pinto – Founder of Dans’Artes

story:
In a nutshell:

I'm raising funds to continue my graduate studies in Expressive Arts Therapy and Conflict Transformation. My university offers a matching scholarship, where they match the amount raised from family and friends who support this degree.

What is Expressive Arts?

This degree is an MA in Expressive Arts Therapy and Conflict Transformation & Peace Building. Essentially, I am studying how five art disciplines (visual art, music, dance/movement, poetry/creative writing, and theatre) can all be used together in various situations and populations to stimulate positive changes. Expressive Arts therapists work in hospitals with the terminally ill, in nursing homes, schools, and in mental health fields. We also work with victims of domestic violence, the incarcerated, the homeless, war veterens, and with refugees.  Your donations can impact a wide range of populations with specific needs, plus you will be supporting the arts in health and society. 

Projects underway:

For my internships, I am currently implementing an Expressive Arts program in San Diego Youth Services' CAT program where I facilitate groups of "at-risk youth." The program is an after school program with the goal of buiding social skills, skills in healthy self-expression, and building a sense of community through the arts and play. I'm implementing another Expressive Arts program at the San Diego Girls Rehabilitation Facility where I work individually with adolecent girls who've experienced traumatic situations such as human trafficking and domestic abuse. The sessions use a solution-focused approach with the goal of building self-esteem, empowerment, and healthy self-expression.

Funding goal:

My goal is $2000. The amount raised, regardless of reaching the goal or not,  will go to my university and will be applied to this summer school's tuition wherein the university will match it. 

If contributing even the smallest amount carries too much of a burden, please share this page via Facebook, Twitter, and any other social media or website to encourage support from others who may be interested in supporting.

With gratitude,

Michelle L. Josey

story:
Summary

The Benton Main Street organization welcomes the Children’s Art Center to Benton and encourages all who hear about this permanent and valuable addition to our community to “Cover Our Kids”!

“We Are Marshall County and We Cover Our Kids” is a campaign designed to raise funds for a part of the original Children’s Art Center in downtown Benton that was cut from the budget due to lack of funding.  The brick canopy is already designed and in the building plans and the $25,000 raised will complete that structure to provide shelter from adverse weather while dropping off our kids.

What We Need & What You Get

The Children’s Art Center is currently under construction and is the culmination of ten years of planning, fundraising and outreach.  The Center has obtained grants, gifts, loans and in-kind contributions but still is short of its goal in its capital campaign.  Accordingly, it had to cut the canopy from the construction budget.  Happily the rest of the project is well underway and should be completed in early fall 2013.

For many years, the Marshall County Arts Commission has served the young people of Marshall County in various locations such as schools, city and county government buildings and private facilities.  We are now so close to realizing the dream of a public community space dedicated to all who appreciate the value of arts education and experience.

Now to the Fun Part

There are many faces of Marshall County that we want to showcase as our own public art project, to visibly show the community commitment to the Arts Center.

People across the county will be photographed over the next few weeks and their images will be displayed everywhere throughout the county.Then at end end of our project we will host a GRAND REVEAL where you will be an honored guest! The REVEAL is scheduled for June 15, 2013 - more details to follow!  There are a number of ways that contributors can participate even if they don’t want their picture taken and displayed.  As a matter of fact, even if you can’t contribute you can help us get the word out!

We know that this will inspire lots of folks to think how they may promote family members, friends, pets etc. as worthy of praise for their accomplishments and pride for Marshall County and its dedication to the arts.

There are different levels of participation, each of which is awarded a Perk!  As you can see from our Perks column, there are many fun ways to contribute and get some goodies.

Check out where you feel most motivated and tell your family, friends and neighbors about this unique way to show our pride and love for our kids.

Any funds raised in excess of our goal or under our goal will be used as the Marshall County Arts Commission may direct for the construction and operation of the Children’s Art Center so no money will go unused or unappreciated.

The Benton Main Street Program is a 501 (c)(3) non-profit whose mission is to bring together all segments of the community to foster civic pride, promote economic vitality and preserve and develop our cultural and historic resources.

story:
Who Are We?

The Kaiju Flambeaux Corps is one of the newest and most ambitious groups to join the ranks of the Intergalactic Krewe of Chewbacchus.  In fine BacchanALIEN form,  we are updating the ancient parade tradition of processional torchbearers with space age technology and DIY artistry.

What Is A "Kaiju"?

"Kaiju" are the 'giant monsters' of Japanese cinema such as Godzilla and Rodan. We are creating a New Orleanian Kaiju of our very own for the Chewbacchus Parade... a 10 foot tall fire-breathing robotic MechaGator! 

This monstrous guardian of the swamps will roll at the head of the Chewbacchus parade on February 22, 2014 (pending NOFD and neighborhood association approval) and will make appearances at regional and national festivals for years to come.

What Is A "Flambeaux"?

“Flambeaux” are traditional kerosene lamps on poles that lit the way for parade floats before electricity.  They remain a cherished part of Mardi Gras celebrations. We are also building a series of modernized Flambeaux "Sticks" that will run on clean burning propane controlled by high-tech electronics and valves. While staying true to traditional forms, these controlled flame effects will boldly go where no flambeaux has gone before. Our artists will craft the usual sheet metal reflectors into fabulous cityscapes menaced by Kaiju creatures of nightmare and fantasy.

The Kaiju Flambeaux Corps needs YOUR support in our quest to bring our new version of amazing flame effects to Mardi Gras and beyond. We have assembled a crack team of engineers, designers, builders, programmers, artists and doers from the amazing talent pool in the Krewe of Chewbacchus and the New Orleans Burner Community. Our long-term goal is to use inspiring projects to harness the incredible talents of our group of incredible drunken nerds for the benefit of the people, culture and environment of New Orleans.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $2,000 via Indiegogo to support this incredible project.  The Krewe of Chewbacchus has supported and funded the creation of the MechaGator to the tune of $1,000 already.  The trailer, chassis and steel armature of the beast is well on its way towards completion.  The New Orleans Burner Community has also invested their time, energy and resources to create a working propane vaporizer unit.  We have also built a working prototype of our Flambeaux "Sticks".

Our $2,000 Indiegogo Goal will give us $1,000 to match the Chewbacchus funding for the MechaGator and finish it.  It will also give us a $1,000 budget to build two complete Flambeaux "Sticks".

If we exceed our $2,000 funding goal the extra funds will be used to add a whole range of upgrades to the MechaGator and Flambeaux Sticks including: LEDs, Fog Machines, Lasers, Interactive Audio and other Special FX.  We promise to spend the money on making these awesome toys even MORE incredible!

We have some truly awesome rewards for people who donate to our cause, including stickers, t-shirts, mono-prints, homemade MechaGator Mardi Gras beads and more!

SUPPORT OUR AMAZING PROJECT AND HELP US BRING FLAME FX TO THE CHEWBACCHUS PARADE AND BEYOND!

story:
Our Story

My name is Laura Juzenaite and I’m Chief Organiser of an exciting event called ‘I AM AN ACTOR’. 

 

‘I AM AN ACTOR’ is an exclusive networking event to help undiscovered actors meet casting directors, agents and industry professionals. It isn't easy to get that lucky break and 'I AM AN ACTOR' is here to change that. 20 professional actors oozing with potential and charisma star in this special event as the newest talent in town!


An original short film called Schizophrenia and Me and Me, featuring the actors, will be premiered during the evening, followed by a casual meet and drink to kick start that 'oh so important' networking! A DVD of the film, as well as a program containing the actors’ contact details will be given to each guest. And to top that, 20 individual mock movie posters of Schizophrenia and Me and Me will be on display. Each actor will star in his or her own poster of the film.


We are looking for private donations as well as sponsors and businesses interested in associating themselves with the 'I AM AN ACTOR' project. We need help in reaching our goal of hosting the 'I AM AN ACTOR' networking event at the prestigious BAFTA venue on Piccadilly in London.


Come and play a part in making undiscovered talent; discovered talent.

We won't be able to do it with out you!

story:
As a youth, I grew up in the Pasadena California area attending all local schools beginning with Longfellow Elementary, Elliot Junior High (above) and John Muir High School.

After high school I attended Pasadena City College where I majored in architecture and art.     I built many scale models of various buildings such as the Tramway in Palm Springs, the Swedish Covenant Hospital in Chicago Illinois and the Emanuel Medical Center in Turlock California and this Star Trek Enterprise (above).

In 1989 I started drawing with pen and ink, and slowly began to add color (below).



Most drawings are 22” x 28” but some are also 27"x 40"(above).

As I drew more I did peoples homes (above) and sold a few.  I also drew from imagination as seen below.  Notice the detailed in these enlarged images below.




 Wall Art at Color.

As a regular customer at the Altadena Golf Course in the Pasadena area, I’ve met a friend who wanted to know if I could draw color paintings on walls inside his home.
I accepted his job request of doing Spanish tiles on this stair well. 

The entire project took about 3 ½ weeks. As in the stair case scene, it was  all done from imagination.  The entire drawing was outlined in pencil and then in marking tape.



The second project was a European Corner table chair and shelf above.  This idea was given to me be homeowner.  He wanted it very large and life size, it ended up to be over eight feet wide and four feet tall.  The masking tape was used to outline every detail and area. 

The masking process was repeated at least 100 times to complete the many layers of color and detail.  When completed the table and chair will appear to be flat while drawn in a corner of the room. Every detail was done in three dimensions.


WHAT I NEED FROM YOU.

I am trying to raise $37,500.00 in which:

- $17,500 will be used to create a line of Pen & Ink art books.

- $12,500 will be used for Pen & Ink Puzzles, Calendars, Mugs, T-shirts etc.

- $7,500 marketing and supplies 

I have a list of gifts that you will receive upon your contribution.

I understand that sometime it’s not possible to make a contribution.  Please feel free to contribute by emailing your friends about my campaign.  This to is very beneficial in helping me reach my goals.

DONATION USAGE

As I receive donations I plan to market my work nation wide including, books, puzzles, glassware, wallpaper,  pottery, floor tiles etc.  I want to create children’s coloring books and expand to teaching aides using tee shirts to show math symbols and alphabetical letters as a great learning tool.

These donations will enable me to reach many more eager merchants & buyers.

I wish to thank you and Indiegogo for enabling me to develop my talents.

story:
Valeria's Wings... Is That Like an Airline or Something?!

No! We are aerialists, which means we do stuff like this:

and this:

"Memphis is incredibly rich in all genres of the arts: dance, theatre, music, visual arts," says Val Russell, artistic director of Valeria's Wings. "But one thing that is really lacking in this city is a strong physical theatre company making cutting-edge, groundbreaking work. Cities like New York, Chicago, San Francisco have really amazing companies like Streb and Pilabolus... Long-term, I want to bring that to Memphis. Short-term, this show will be the first step toward educating the Memphis public about this exciting movement."

Where is "The Great American Backyard"?

Good question. We all seem to be stuck in front of flickering screens these days, kids and adults alike. Whatever happened to playing outside, spinning around under the trees until you fell down dizzy, hanging off of monkey bars, playing baseball until it got too dark to see the ball? We want to capture the essence and spirit of The Great American Backyard, and bring it back to life... on a stage... with aerial performers, dancers, musicians, spoken word artists, video gurus, and more. It's called physical theatre... and you can play with us!

Physical Theatre? Huh?!

Physical theatre is a genre of theatrical performance that pursues storytelling through primarily physical means, rather than relying on text (like a Shakespeare play). In a basic sense, you "talk" through body language, hand gestures, thought track and many more physical features.

The Nitty-Gritty

Numbers aren't necessarily our strong suit, but we know that you want to know where your money is going. So, here are the details:

  • Every dollar raised will go directly toward the production of this show. That includes choreography, building original play structures that will be used in the show and for community outreach, original music, and hiring outside performers.
  • If we don't reach our goal, we will still use every cent for the production. We might have to cut back on a couple of things, but we are performers... the show must go on!

The Impact

In addition to creating an awesome and entertaining show, we also envision a long-term impact as a result of the collaboration and impetus from this campaign:

  • There is no other company in Memphis doing this kind of work. We think it's important and groundbreaking and we want to share it with the community.
  • We can use our diverse programming to serve the Memphis community through more shows, educational programs for kids, and support for artists.
  • We can also bring in other artists from outside of Memphis to perform and educate.
  • If the show is successful, we can apply for non-profit status and apply for grant money to do even more awesome shows in the future.

Other Ways You Can Help

Monetary donations are always great, but there are lots of other ways to get involved! Check out the list below, or make up your own supportive ideas. Hope to see you on the playground of life!

  • Share this on Facebook or Twitter or whatever else you kids are on these days.
  • Volunteer for the show!

Keep up with the process on our blog. 

P.S. The show will be at the Duncan-Williams Performing Arts Hall at GPAC, February 28 at 7 p.m.

story:
Short Summary

In 2012 a sober musician was wrongfully accused of manslaughter and imprisoned in a European penitentiary.  In an attempt to help, a fellowship of sober friends and additional members of the sober entertainment community banded together to deliver recovery based email messages to the musician during his incarceration. The email list, aptly named SFG, has since flowered into a support network for sober Artists to connect with one another while touring domestically and abroad. 

In 2013 an SFG founding member, Tommy Vext partnered with Aaron Robin to form a unique non-profit organization aptly named SFG12 to expand on the original SFG.  The main goal of SFG12 is to provide a safety net of critical aid for recovering artists seeking assistance.

In addition, SFG12 offers a wide range of sober support:

1)  Customized treatment needs

2)  Uniquely designed financial programs

3)  Spiritual assistance programs

4)  Sponsorship

5)  Touring Sober Companionship

6)  Touring Meeting Scheduling

7)  Peer support groups

8)  Sober living

9)  Detox admissions

SFG12 

Hi, my name is Aaron Robin.  I am the co-founder and CEO of SFG12. 

My story is simple and a bit cliché amongst most who’ve won the battle with drug and alcohol addiction: I had drank and used with reckless disregard for long enough, had hit rock bottom, and in 2006 made a conscious decision to get sober and turn my life around.  Looking back now, that decision was the single most important moment in my life and quite possibly the best thing I have ever done.

Fast forward to 2013, when I reunited with long-time friend Tommy Vext and first heard about SFG.  His commitment to helping others inspired me to do the same and so SFG12 was born.  Cleaning up my life has been the hardest thing I’ve ever faced.  While I’ve had the good fortune of supportive friends and family along the way, there are those less fortunate than I who are in desperate need of support to help them overcome their addiction. 

During these last eight years of sobriety, I have seen a lot of people struggle to get clean. I’ve come to realize just how challenging dealing with an addiction can be.  It is a ruthless disease that affects both those afflicted and those whose lives are closely tied to the sufferer. 

I made a decision in September to change my life in an effort to change many more. Thank you everybody for the support. I’m so excited to be part of SFG12!


Who our services are for? 

Artist Helping Artist

SFG12’s services are for any “Artist” that is dealing with Drug and Alcohol addiction. 

·  A definition of Artist from Princeton.edu: creative person (a person whose creative work shows sensitivity and imagination)

·  Musicians

·  Actors and Actresses

·  Drawers

·  Painters

·  Sculptures

·  Dancers

·  Writers

·  Filmmakers

·  Photographers

People who use imagination, talent, or skill to create works that may be judged to have an aesthetic value.


What our services do?

Our services are there to help people in times of need. When you or someone you love or are concerned about needs help with drug and or alcohol addiction, we are a lifeline for you to reach out to.

Break down of services:

  • Detox
  • Rehab 
  • Sober Livings
  • Sober Companionship 

SFG12 allocates $2000 - $5000 per Client depending on their individual circumstances.  Donations help us get struggling artists off the street and in to a safe environment to begin receiving help. Help us to make a difference! 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you like what we are doing and just don't have the means to contribute, don't worry you can still help.

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. 
  • Share about us and the difference we are making on Facebook. www.facebook.com/SFG12
  • Follow us on Instagram and Twitter @SFG12_ 
  • Volunteer your time for are next event 
  • Don't forget use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Jeremy Garrison finds home in many places, from the kentucky woods to the chicago metropolitan area  to any of many seasonal retreats.  Between visits "home" he enjoys nannying for the 6 year old daughter of a touring band.  His greatest passions are community, sustainability, music, children and, recently, fermenting, 

You can find Krystalyn Norton virtually anywhere in the Americas.  She's an artist, especially enjoying repurposing fabrics, upcycling jewelry, and henna art.  Her latest and greatest passion has been lifestyle coaching, helping people integrate their diet, their exercise regiment, and their interpersonal relationships into a healthy life.

They both lead gypsy lives, almost always travelling.  Still, they strive to lead healthy lives and to surround themselves with community. They wish to share several ways to make our lives full of luxury.

 

1.  Community

     We both lead lives of service.  Wherever our lives take us, we bring many skills and offer them freely.  We allow whatever community we become a part of to meet our needs.

2.  Diet

     A luxurious life begins with a conscious diet and plenty of exercise.  We strive to find local foods that are free of pesticides, hormones and genetic modifications and are always willing to pay it forward.  This usually means shopping at local, independant stores rather than the chains.

3.  Enjoying life's often simple pleasures

     There's always time to visit places of natural beauty, communities of like-minds, and holistic healers.

4.  Follow your passions

     This might be the most important component.  We choose our endevours based on what will bring joy and fullfillment rather than the next paycheck.  Life never fails to provide necessary resources.

 

As we travel, we can choose the highways or the byways.  The quickest way from one place to another often involves routes that bypass the small towns that are the country's backbone and often avoid the vibrant cities as well.  By taking alternate routes, we can immerse ourselves in the communities we traverse and in the natural beauties that exist everywhere.  The HIghway 127 sale is the "world's longest yard sale", stretching 690 miles from Michigan to Alabama.  Follow us as we shop small-town America, see some of the Midwest's natural wonders and live the life we love!

 

The funds we raise with this campaign will get us started with the technology and training we need to document our travels.  It's only the beginning.  We have alot to share and believe that there are many people who would make similar choices if they believed it was possible!  We've chosen "perks" to offer to begin sharing some our favorite practices...

story:
Modern Starlet is a photography book conceived by Lauren Carter.  This coffee table/ art photography book  has secured a publishing contract with Schiffer Publishing.  The book is inspired by the art of photography, and takes a particular interest in the makeup, lighting techniques, clothing, and poses of eras bygone.  The book features collaborations between top photographers, models, and stylists all in a style influenced by Old Hollywood.  

Beautiful photography requires planning and a budget, and in order to realize this book to its potential, Lauren and her assistant, Sarah Szot, are planning on one additional shoot to be set in a beautiful Spanish Mission in California with top Los Angeles-based agency models, and makeup supplied by a top makeup artist proficient in the vintage style.  It is for this shoot specifically that we have taken to indiegogo in the hopes of securing funds to complete our (already gorgeous) book.  We are currently on a Dec 1 deadline with Schiffer Publishing with our manuscript, to release the book in early 2015.

We believe this will be a beautiful product which will look stunning on any coffee table or shelf, and look forward to sharing some fabulous perks, such as free signed copies of the book, invitations to the red carpet launch party, and more with those who are able to take part in this project, helping to make this book reach its potential.  


Modern Starlet is pleased to announce we are now donating 10% of all proceeds of this fundraising campaign, as well as 10% of all profit on book sales to Earthchild Project. To learn more about this organization, please see below and visit

www.earthchildproject.org

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tWMXNzJgPPM

http://www.givengain.com/cause/4558/projects/14785/

"Earthchild Project is a charity organisation operating in disadvantaged primary schools in South Africa. Working with children and teachers their educational programmes focus on the environment, health and lifeskills. They teach practical skills that complement the academic curriculum to over 3 000 children and 150 teachers across 8 schools.  

Earthchild Project aims to inspire a new generation of healthy, confident and conscious young leaders."

story:
Short Summary

Burning Man's environment is a vast social sculpture, a place that encompasses the collective spirit as well as elements of Buddhist teachings, both impermanence and human ritual. In this desert landscape sculpture can speak the language of the sublime.

This is a mother/son collaboration- the sound designer on this project is Justin Harmon Calder who has integrated his art collective /music label, Budo Kiba, into the team and several of the members will be traveling to Burning Man to record the playing of the sculptures in the Black Rock Desert. 

Your contribution to 'Totem Orchestra will make our vision a reality. Together, we are building a community of artisans, providing an amazing arena for new forms of expression with sound and sculpture. The funds raised will help cover the cost of materials, lighting, fabrication of the three sound sculptures  and the video documentation of the work.   

Joan Harmon is offering a selection of her artworks - original drawings, sculptures and prints as perks for your donations.

Please see a the perks below: 

 

Footpath Drawing

 

          We Walk the Bottom of an Ocean We Call Sky

 

Boutons-  black glass hand blown sculptural forms

 

Hand Blown Small Glass Vessels

 

Night River

 

 

If you are unable to contribute, please share on your social media, email or word of mouth. We thank you for your continued support!
