By donating just a small amount towards my project you will help me cast models (they are expensive!) also travel and refreshments to be supplied to them. (As University does not contribute funding towards any project, therefore this platform would be vital to make my concept REAL!)
The ImpactMy project will hopefully show to the public that every woman is beautiful and can still be stylish bright and bold and classy, whatever your age, size or flaws!The more diversity children and teens see, the less discrimination and bullying!Breakdown Of Costs:Models: £400Food for the models: £30Cost of final photo book printing: £100Cost of photography portfolio box: £30Great casting is essential, if I do not reach my goal of £500 your funding will still help towards booking some fantastic models and taking me one step further towards the project I would love to create. If you are unable to contribute you can still help by getting the word out about my project on Facebook, Twitter and other social networking sites. Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools (:Please e-mail me if there are any queries at chantroxer@aol.comor inbox me using my Facebook link! www.facebook.com/chantellerowleyphotography

story:
About Fotoii Mag

My name is Marcel. It was in April 2006 that I first launched fotoii.com, a website devoted to photography. Showcasing the work of talented photographers from around the world, it has now been seven years since we have served as an online community and virtual exhibition space. As exciting and wonderful as this enterprise has been, however, we wanted something more – the printed page — a classic format that has, for decades, proven to be one of the best ways of presenting photographic images to a wider public. With Fotoii Mag, everything — from the paper stock to the page layout, to the text — will be in service of the image and the image alone.

As you will see over the following pages, Fotoii Mag really runs the gamut of photography, showcasing photographers who not only come from around the world but who also and perhaps more importantly given the hyperconnectivity of our world, take radically different approaches to their medium.

Our Finance needs

In order to publish the next Fotoii Magazine Issue 002, we need your help in raising 6'000 €. This money will allow us to print 1000 magazines and support national and international photographers. 

  • 3'000 € print costs
  • 1'000 € shipping costs, costs for the writers and graphic design 
  • 2'000 € fees for photographers

In exchange for your belt in sowing the seeds, we have some exiting perks to thanks you for your support.

Please donate and make the Fotoii Issue 002 become a reality!

What do I get in return?

To thank you for your help we have prepared somer perks that you will find in the right column on this page. If you wish to know more details about our perks check our website : 

http://www.fotoii.com/magazine or

http://issuu.com/fotoii/docs/fotoii_01_web


Thanks for sharing this campaign with your friends

story:
Hello everyone,

My son, Collin, and I are huge fans of fighting games (specifically Street Fighter, Marvel, and Killer Instinct). After watching this year's Evo, we made a decision to save money to go to next year's Evo. Collin also has some skills in drawing (they're pretty hilarious). So I had an idea to raise money by having him draw for people. Any character/competitor/etc. Although I will buy tickets for both of us, I thought it'd be nice to see people requesting his drawings. They may not be amazing, but will surely put a smile on your face. 


(Some more images in the gallery)

story:
Kinetic Fire Sculpture for Burning Man

Hello - My name is Anton Viditz-Ward.

I am currently building a new art piece for Burning Man 2014. I live and work in Telluride, CO, with our studio space at Deep Creek Mine. My crew and I build these projects with funding from Burning Man, our local Arts council, and fundraisers we hold at my studio. However, these sources of funding are not enough. I am asking for your help, to offset the out of pocket costs of providing artwork this size for the masses. If you have seen my projects at Burning Man in the past, I hope you will be driven to help us get a whole new sculpture out to the playa. If you are new to my work, check out the pictures and video to get an idea of what we are doing. These have been some of the most mesmerizing natural fire sculptures at the event in the last several years. Any help would be greatly appreciated!

I put lots of time planning the look and feel of this piece to work it into this years theme, Caravansary. The detail work will include rotoscope style cutouts and images on the sides of the wheels. The base structure has Rumi script laser cut into it. The hand cranks for operating the wheels are newly cut and architecturally designed. The overall concept of fire and crowd interaction has been embraced and brought to the forefront.

The money raised will be used to pay for steel, transportation, and all wearable materials used to build the project (like welding supplies, chains, gears, nuts, bolts, etc....). I build these projects with no pay, and my volunteers all work for free and hold full time jobs. We bring these projects to Burning Man to share with the community, and we also display and share these works locally when we can.

Unlike traditional artwork, these contraptions are costly to build and maintain, and will slowly destroy themselves over time. They require a lot of maintenance to run, as well as countless hours for our volunteers to manage spectator safety, debris clean up, and set up/tear down. We also incur a good bit of costs getting them back and forth to the playa (steel is heavy!).


What We Need & What You Get

We have purchased raw materials, but we still need your help:

  • Funds raised will cover our construction costs, as well as transportation back and forth to the event.
  • If we don't reach our goal, every dollar donated will be used to make the project a reality and get the project and our crew out to Burning Man.
  • If we go over our goal, we will use excess money to make improvements to our studio, purchase tools and equipment, and continue working even harder to bring exciting new interactive artwork to the public.
  • We have some great perks! (We have decided to skip the stickers, shirts and other trinkets, which ultimately cost us more money) Check them out, donate, then come spend some time with the crew out on the playa.


Past Projects

I have built five of these projects for Burning Man and our community in the past:

  • Fire Spinner (2007) 
  • The Wheel of Thwarted Ambition (2008)
  • Palindrome (2009)
  • Towering Inferno (2010)
  • Bapteme Du Feu (2012)


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can't contribute money, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • If you can't donate, please spread the word and get this to someone who can . If you can help at Burning Man, we can use a hand cleaning up nightly at the project, you can help us run it, or you can help us take it down and load it to go home. 
  • Please share this campaign on Facebook, through personal emails, anywhere that will get the word out and make this a success. Tell anyone and everyone you know in the Burning Man community!

Check us out and like us here:  Deep Creek Experimental

Thanks so much!!!

story:
• Touch controls
  • 15+ levels
  • Character customization
  • Multiple game types


We are asking for $550.

Where is this money going?

  • $100 to buy an Apple store publishing license
  • $50 of taxes and fees (Indiegogo)
  • $150 Publishing fees
  • $200 Final polish/compatibility  
  • $50 Emergency bacon funds



Given the nature of the app and how much money we are asking for we do not have tons of premium swag to go along with our game. However we do have straightforward perks that offer a good value.


Click on the link to try a small sample of what our game has to offer. It is compatible with most computers and operating systems. Also please keep in mind that the game is designed for mobile devices so it is optimized for touch screen controls and resolutions.

Try The Demo!

Update: After some valuable feedback we have added a tutorial for the controls in the gallery section. An improved tutorial will also be added to the final game.


The FlingFormer team is made up of 4 Champlain College students in the game development program. We have a producer (Colin), Designer (Lee), and two programmers (Dan and Abner).

FlingFormer has been developed over the past several weeks as a school project, but we were so happy with the project that we wanted to continue the development and publish the game as a mobile app.  By helping us reach our goal not only are you helping our Dream come true, but you are getting a fun game in the process.



This project means a lot to all the members of the team. It is the first game we have made that we actually put on the market. This has been a learning experience all around and hopefully this will be the first of many games to come. By funding our game you are doing a lot more than just buying yourself a fun game. You are making it possible for us to continue doing what we love.



If our funding goal is exceeded it will give our team the ability to add more to the game. 

$1000 - More levels!

$1500 - A new game type

$3000 - More player customizations and improved sound and general polish.

story:
“Contemporary Artists Respond to the New Orleans Baby Dolls” is an exhibition of art about and inspired by the Baby Doll masking tradition. There are few artistic representations of this little known tradition. The artists will be able to create works about a visually undocumented practice dating back to around 1912 that has endured as a living art form through the current day. The show engages in the important work of educating, preserving and making contemporary a cultural heritage that has gone virtually ignored.  The show will open in the Spring of 2015 at the George & Leah McKenna Museum of African American Art in New Orleans.

Who Are the Baby Dolls? The Baby Dolls are groups of  women and men who used New Orleans street masking as a form of fun and self-expression in a time when it was usual for women to do that.  Wearing short dresses, bloomers, bonnets, garters with money tucked tight, they strutted, sang ribald songs, chanted and danced often with mock bands on Mardi Gras and St. Joseph feast night.  The practice started around 1912 and while it waxed and waned, has endured to the present day.

Purposes of the Exhibit:  The goals of the exhibition are to tell the story of the New Orleans Baby Dolls through the visual arts.

The Art: The work in this show by established and emerging artists will include a variety of media: painting, drawing, sculpture, ceramics, printmaking, and graphic arts etc. by established and emerging artists.  Work by all professional and emerging artists is enthusiastically welcomed will be featured using the Baby Doll masking practice theme as a catalyst. 

Where: The George & Leah McKenna Museum of African American Art is an institution that collects, interprets and preserves the visual aesthetic of people of African descent in North America and beyond. Through innovative programs and exhibits that engage versatile audiences, the McKenna Museum seeks to make African Diaspora fine art accessible to visitors of all ages. The institution also actively identifies and presents emerging artists alongside well-established fine arts masters. Located in New Orleans, the McKenna Museum is committed to the preservation of the distinct culture found within the African American community of Louisiana. 

The Artists: The artists will be invited from a general call. These artists can be trained and experienced or self-taught. All are encouraged to participate in the process. The work will be selected by three jurors: Professor Ron Bechet, Mora Beauchamp-Byrd, Ph.D. and Pamela Franco, Ph.D. based on the quality and the potential to bring a fresh viewpoint to the history and culture of the theme of the “Baby Doll” tradition.

Confirmed Artists

Ann Bruce is a native of New Orleans.  She went to Miss Aiken’s School for Little People and Louise S. McGehee School.  She attended Newcomb College, The University of Florence, and took classes at the New Orleans Academy of Fine Arts.  For as long as she can remember she has been drawing “funny” little things that amuse her.  In the 1970s she began painting her version of landscapes with buildings and little blue and green trees.  In the 80s she added her version of little people into the landscapes.  And in the 90s, she began incorporating New Orleans characters into her paintings.  In 2005 Antoinette K-Doe invited Ann to join the Ernie K-Doe Baby Dolls.  They marched in the Krewe of Muses parade and had a wonderful time struttin’ down the street showing off their “linens.”  Ann loves New Orleans, its traditions, and the magic of Mardi Gras.  As she says “In my pictures, my Baby Dolls do all the things I do and all the wild, crazy things I don’t dare do—I love them and have so much fun with them!”  And, since 2005, she appears in her pictures.  She is not hard to find!

Karen T. La Beau is a native of New Orleans that now resides in Shreveport, La.  She is a self taught, third generation artist. Karen began drawing at that age of 6. She began professionally painting in 2007. That is when she began her series of, “My Life on Canvas.” She said, “I’ve chose to tell my story through visual art. To me, telling my history on canvas, vinyl albums and wood is far more interesting then writing it down on paper. Since my history primarily revolves around the culture of New Orleans and my life in Shreveport as well as happenings all over the state, it’s my goal to exhibit “My Life on Canvas” across the state.” Currently, she is preparing for a solo exhibit titled, “When a Man Loves a Woman.” Karen has private collectors all over the country from California to Maryland. She was honored as a woman artist by the North Louisiana Multicultural Center two years in a row. Several years ago, she began teaching middle school children art in an after school outreach program (Noel Community Arts Program). 

Jamar Duvol Pierre has said that “My introduction to the art world was public art.” Crisp and defined works, beautiful people, rich culture, timeless memories, raw emotions and genuine passion. These are all conclusions one may draw from the first glance at an authentic J. Pierre work. J. Pierre is a celebrated New Orleans artist who vividly gives life to the side of New Orleans that tourists never see. J. Pierre: painter, illustrator, and designer has changed the face of New Orleans art in the eyes of international markets and has worked in an unprecedented variety of styles. His fan base is just as rich and diverse as his work. Any J. Pierre creation is sure to leave a taste of the joie de vivre of New Orleans on your mind, heart and soul.

Steve Prince has said about his art, ”That’s where my visual ministry is focused. That’s where my church is. My art becomes a traveling evangelism show for our contemporary culture, providing answers for today’s troubled world. But it also becomes a celebration; a celebration of that very broken yet extremely beautiful world. The art becomes a bridge to help people find their way from that brokenness to the beauty that I so clearly see.”  He is an artist and art professor residing in Silver Spring, MD concerned with the conditions of humanity and the challenges we face in a society that erodes our sense of true community and communal togetherness. His art creatively explores the challenges and solutions to life's moral, ethical, and spiritual dilemmas. "Bird in Hand: Second Line for Michigan" (pictured in part in the promotional video above) is offered as a symbol for Michigan as it grieves it's economic loss and unites together to rebuild and renew its future.  For more see: An Interview with Steve Prince by Beth McCoy.

Aleta Richard is the teaching artist for McDonogh 42 Elementary Charter School located in the New Orleans historic area, the Treme.  In 2013 she organized her students’ participation in “Home in New Orleans”, an interdisciplinary enrichment program for 5th through 8th grades from McDonogh 42 Elementary Charter School the culminating performance and gallery show took place at the George and Leah McKenna Museum. The evening featured performances by the dance troupe, poets and the drum line. Students were ecstatic to hang their art and photographs in a formal gallery setting; for many of whom this was their first exhibition.  One of her students recalled about the experience that "Some of my favorite things about Home in New Orleans were being able to learn new kinds of dances with my friends, going to the museums, and learning all the history about the art."  In that same year, her students made the signature favors, small hand-made masks for the opening exhibit of the "They Call Me Baby Doll: A Mardi Gras Tradition" held of the Louisiana State Museum Presbytere.  Ms Richard will guide her students to create a visual work that will be used for the exhibition poster for this exhibit "Contemporary Artists respond to The New Orleans Baby Dolls". 

The Jurors:  Three Jurors  will select and cultivate the work for the exhibition.

Mora Beauchamp-Byrd, Ph.D., Interim Director New Orleans African American Museum, is a curator and art historian who specializes in African American Art, the art of the African Diaspora, 18th century British art and visual culture, and contemporary British art with a particular focus on British artists of African, Asian and Caribbean descent. She has served as Assistant Professor of Art History, Department of Art, and Curator of Art Collections, Xavier University of Louisiana. 

Ron Bechet M.F.A was born in New Orleans and holds a B.A. degree in Fine Arts from the University of New Orleans and an M.F.A. in Painting and Drawing from the Yale School of Art, Yale University. He is the Victor H. Labat Professor of Art at Xavier University of Louisiana. Mr. Bechet is the Chair of the Art Department at Xavier University. He is a painter that has exhibited his work nationally and internationally. Mr. Bechet intends for the compositions to be metaphors for abstract concepts and difficult realities, questions of what is real and what is delusional. The rich visual traditions, icons and symbols from Bechet’ s upbringing in New Orleans influence his work, as do his reflections on rituals and formal spiritual practice, particularly from African based cultures. 

Pamela Franco, Ph.D. is a native Trinidadian and earned a PhD in art history from Emory University in Atlanta. She works as a Executive Associate to the Senior Vice President of Academic Affairs at Xavier University. Before that she was an Assistant Professor of Art History at Tulane University. She was a member of the Newcomb Gallery Advisory Board. She was also the Director of a summer abroad program to Trinidad and Tobago. She has been instrumental in organizing symposia and exhibitions on African and Caribbean Art.

Exhibit Organizers: 

Kim Marie Vaz, Ph.D. grew up in New Orleans and attended St. Mary’s Academy and Tulane University’s Newcomb College.  She earned her doctorate in Educational Psychology from Indiana University in Bloomington.  She is the author of The ‘Baby Dolls’: Breaking the Race and Gender Barriers of the New Orleans Mardi Gras Tradition (Louisiana State University Press).  Her book served as the basis for a 2013 major installation on the Baby Doll tradition at the Presbytere unit of the Louisiana State Museum as part of the museum’s permanent display on the history of Carnival in Louisiana. 

Ron Bechet is a native of New Orleans and a relative of the early jazz pioneer Sidney Bechet. He began drawing in the fourth grade, studied art at the University of New Orleans and went on to earn a graduate degree from Yale University. He his art teaching career began at Delgado Community College, then at Southern University in New Orleans and, since 1998, at Xavier. Even though he is a celebrated and accomplished artist, he feels he learns as much about himself and his art while teaching as his students do in their own studies. One of the biggest influences on his recent work was fellow art professor at Xavier, the renowned sculptor, the late John T. Scott. 

Jennifer Williams is Museum Director and Curator of The McKenna Museum of African American Art.  She received her B.A. in History with a concentration in Art History from Georgia State University in Atlanta, GA. With the guiding spirit of her parent’s dedication of serving others throughout their lives, she moved to New Orleans to serve as an AmeriCorps VISTA coordinating projects with the Tulane University Center for Public Service at a community center in the 7th ward. Serving 3 terms over, her commitment to social justice has grown.  As curator she has the responsibility of finding artists willing and interested in supporting the McKenna by allowing the museum to feature and showcase their work within the city. 

Funding Use: Funds will be used to help defray the cost of insuring the collection, installation and publicity.  Additional funding over the pledged amount will be used to design and distribute a catalog, for educational programming, for an opening reception, and to defray the cost of  associated fees such as postage for mailing the rewards . 

Rewards: For their contribution each backer will receive recognition on social media (e.g., the exhibit's Facebook page and website) and his or her name on our list of donors on display at the exhibition. Depending on the amount pledged backers can receive up to three digital copies or prints of a Baby Doll masking by one of three well regarded photographers, an exhibition poster, a commemorative second-line handkerchief and bead throw, an autographed copy of the book, "The Baby Dolls" by Kim Vaz, and a docent tour of the exhibit by one of the organizers. 

We would like to thank the three highly regarded photographers for allowing us to use their photographs as gifts to our backers: Romain Breauxis, Phillip Colwart, and Kim Welsh.

Biographies of Photographers:

Romain Breauxis is originally from France and is an avid explorer of New Orleans and Southern Louisiana culture. Through his photos, he tries to capture some of the richness, joyfulness and fascination that he has witnessed during his adventures!

Phillip Colwart was born in Baton Rouge and raised in New Orleans.  He is a Hammond-based professional photographer who contributes his time and photography to the Mardi Gras Indian, Baby Doll and Skull & Bones community.  Having grown to appreciate and value this culture, Phillip gives back to these groups through his photography and thus helps to preserve and perpetuate these traditions.

Kim Welsh enjoys capturing the flavor of urban cultural life and celebration in our unique home, New Orleans. She advocates for cultural preservation and aim to understand the unique world view of her subjects and to respectfully translate that using visual imagery. For Welsh, our diverse, vibrant, and spectacular cultural traditions should always be protected and encouraged as they are our treasure which enriches our lives and often goes unappreciated.

Profile Image:  A frame from circa 1928-1931 footage of the Baby Dolls on Mardi Gras in New Orleans, Louisiana.  Image is owned by Story Sloane’s Galleries Inc., one of the largest private sources for vintage and historic photography in the south.  For more visit: http://www.sloanegallery.com/


Other Ways You Can Help

•Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.

•Use the Indiegogo share tools.

•Leave comments on this page about our campaign.

•Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/artaboutbabydolls?ref=hl

•Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/artaboutBD

•You can make "in-kind" donations.  For example, if you are a caterer, we'd love to discuss with you the opportunity for you to donate your catering services for the opening reception.  If you are a printer, we would love for you to donate to the project by donating your service to print our exhibit poster.

•Want to know more? Email us at kimmvaz@gmail.com or rjbechet@yahoo.com

The show engages in the important work of educating, preserving and making contemporary a cultural heritage that has gone virtually ignored.  The show will open in the Spring of 2015 at the George & Leah McKenna Museum of African American Art in New Orleans.Who Are the Baby Dolls? The Baby Dolls are groups of  women and men who used New Orleans street masking as a form of fun and self-expression in a time when it was usual for women to do that.  Wearing short dresses, bloomers, bonnets, garters with money tucked tight, they strutted, sang ribald songs, chanted and danced often with mock bands on Mardi Gras and St. Joseph feast night.  The practice started around 1912 and while it waxed and waned, has endured to the present day.Purposes of the Exhibit:  The goals of the exhibition are to tell the story of the New Orleans Baby Dolls through the visual arts.The Art: The work in this show by established and emerging artists will include a variety of media: painting, drawing, sculpture, ceramics, printmaking, and graphic arts etc. by established and emerging artists.  Work by all professional and emerging artists is enthusiastically welcomed will
be featured using the Baby Doll masking practice theme as a catalyst. Where: The George & Leah McKenna Museum of African American Art is an institution that collects, interprets and preserves the visual aesthetic of people of African descent in North America and beyond. Through innovative programs and exhibits that engage versatile audiences, the McKenna Museum seeks to make African Diaspora fine art accessible to visitors of all ages. The institution also actively identifies and presents emerging artists alongside well-established fine arts masters. Located in New Orleans, the McKenna Museum is committed to the preservation of the distinct culture found within the African American community of Louisiana. The Artists: The artists will be invited from a general call. These artists can be trained and experienced or self-taught. All are encouraged to participate in the process. The work will be selected by three jurors: Professor Ron Bechet, Mora Beauchamp-Byrd, Ph.D. and Pamela Franco, Ph.D. based on the quality and the potential to bring a fresh viewpoint to the history and culture of the theme of the “Baby Doll” tradition.Confirmed ArtistsAnn Bruce is a native of New Orleans.  She went to Miss Aiken’s School for Little
People and Louise S. McGehee School.  She
attended Newcomb College, The University of Florence, and took classes at the
New Orleans Academy of Fine Arts.  For as
long as she can remember she has been drawing “funny” little things that amuse
her.  In the 1970s she began painting her
version of landscapes with buildings and little blue and green trees.  In the 80s she added her version of little
people into the landscapes.  And in the
90s, she began incorporating New Orleans characters into her paintings.  In 2005 Antoinette K-Doe invited Ann to join
the Ernie K-Doe Baby Dolls.  They marched
in the Krewe of Muses parade and had a wonderful time struttin’ down the street
showing off their “linens.”  Ann loves
New Orleans, its traditions, and the magic of Mardi Gras.  As she says “In my pictures, my Baby Dolls do
all the things I do and all the wild, crazy things I don’t dare do—I love them
and have so much fun with them!”  And,
since 2005, she appears in her pictures. 
She is not hard to find!Karen T. La Beau is a native of New
 Orleans that now resides in Shreveport,
 La.  She is a self taught, third generation
artist. Karen began drawing at that age of 6. She began professionally painting
in 2007. That is when she began her series of, “My Life on Canvas.” She said,
“I’ve chose to tell my story through visual art. To me, telling my history on
canvas, vinyl albums and wood is far more interesting then writing it down on
paper. Since my history primarily revolves around the culture of New Orleans and my life in Shreveport as well as happenings all over the
state, it’s my goal to exhibit “My Life on Canvas” across the state.”
Currently, she is preparing for a solo exhibit titled, “When a Man Loves a
Woman.” Karen has private collectors all over the country from California to Maryland.
She was honored as a woman artist by the North Louisiana
 Multicultural Center
two years in a row. Several years ago, she began teaching middle school
children art in an after school outreach program (Noel Community Arts Program). Jamar Duvol Pierre has said that “My introduction to the art world was public art.” Crisp and defined works, beautiful people, rich culture, timeless memories, raw emotions and genuine passion. These are all conclusions one may draw from the first glance at an authentic J. Pierre work. J. Pierre is a celebrated New Orleans artist who vividly gives life to the side of New Orleans that tourists never see. J. Pierre: painter, illustrator, and designer has changed the face of New Orleans art in the eyes of international markets and has worked in an unprecedented variety of styles. His fan base is just as rich and diverse as his work. Any J. Pierre creation is sure to leave a taste of the joie de vivre of New Orleans on your mind, heart and soul.Steve Prince has said about his art, ”That’s where my visual ministry is focused. That’s where my church is. My art becomes a traveling evangelism show for our contemporary culture, providing answers for today’s troubled world. But it also becomes a celebration; a celebration of that very broken yet extremely beautiful world. The art becomes a bridge to help people find their way from that brokenness to the beauty that I so clearly see.”  He is an artist and art professor residing in Silver Spring, MD concerned with the conditions of humanity and the challenges we face in a society that erodes our sense of true community and communal togetherness. His art creatively explores the challenges and solutions to life's moral, ethical, and spiritual dilemmas. "Bird in Hand: Second Line for Michigan" (pictured in part in the promotional video above) is offered as a symbol for Michigan as it grieves it's economic loss and unites together to rebuild and renew its future.  For more see: An Interview with Steve Prince by Beth McCoy.Aleta Richard is the teaching artist for McDonogh 42 Elementary Charter School located in the New Orleans historic area, the Treme.  In 2013 she organized her students’ participation in “Home
in New Orleans”, an interdisciplinary enrichment program for 5th through 8th
grades from McDonogh 42 Elementary Charter School the culminating
performance and gallery show took place at the George and Leah McKenna Museum.
The evening featured performances by the dance troupe, poets and
the drum line. Students were ecstatic to hang their art and photographs in
a formal gallery setting; for many of whom this was their first
exhibition.  One of her students recalled about the experience that "Some
of my favorite things about Home in New Orleans were being able to learn new
kinds of dances with my friends, going to the museums, and learning all the
history about the art."  In that same year, her students made the signature favors, small hand-made masks for the opening exhibit of the "They Call Me Baby Doll: A Mardi Gras Tradition" held of the Louisiana State Museum Presbytere.  Ms Richard will guide her students to create a visual work that will be used for the exhibition poster for this exhibit "Contemporary Artists respond to The New Orleans Baby Dolls". The Jurors:  Three Jurors  will select and cultivate the work for the exhibition.Mora Beauchamp-Byrd, Ph.D., Interim Director New Orleans African American Museum, is a curator and art historian who specializes in African American Art, the art of the African Diaspora, 18th century British art and visual culture, and contemporary British art with a particular focus on British artists of African, Asian and Caribbean descent. She has served as Assistant Professor of Art History, Department of Art, and Curator of Art Collections, Xavier University of Louisiana. Ron Bechet M.F.A was born in New Orleans and holds a B.A. degree in Fine Arts from the University of New Orleans and an M.F.A. in Painting and Drawing from the Yale School of Art, Yale University. He is the Victor H. Labat Professor of Art at Xavier University of Louisiana. Mr. Bechet is the Chair of the Art Department at Xavier University. He is a painter that has exhibited his work nationally and internationally. Mr. Bechet intends for the compositions to be metaphors for abstract concepts and difficult realities, questions of what is real and what is delusional. The rich visual traditions, icons and symbols from Bechet’ s upbringing in New Orleans influence his work, as do his reflections on rituals and formal spiritual practice, particularly from African based cultures. Pamela Franco, Ph.D. is a native Trinidadian and earned a PhD in art history from Emory University in Atlanta. She works as a Executive Associate to the Senior Vice President of Academic Affairs at Xavier University. Before that she was an Assistant Professor of Art History at Tulane University. She was a member of the Newcomb Gallery Advisory Board. She was also the Director of a summer abroad program to Trinidad and Tobago. She has been instrumental in organizing symposia and exhibitions on African and Caribbean Art.Exhibit Organizers: Kim Marie Vaz, Ph.D. grew up in New Orleans and
attended St. Mary’s Academy and Tulane
University’s Newcomb College.  She earned her doctorate in Educational
Psychology from Indiana University in Bloomington.  She is the author of The
‘Baby Dolls’: Breaking the Race and Gender Barriers of the New Orleans Mardi
Gras Tradition (Louisiana State University Press).  Her book served as the basis for a 2013 major
installation on the Baby Doll tradition at the Presbytere unit of the Louisiana
State Museum as part of the museum’s permanent display on the history of
Carnival in Louisiana.  Ron Bechet is a native of New Orleans and a relative of the early jazz pioneer Sidney Bechet. He began drawing in the fourth grade, studied art at the University of New Orleans and went on to earn a graduate degree from Yale University. He his art teaching career began at Delgado Community College, then at Southern University in New Orleans and, since 1998, at Xavier. Even though he is a celebrated and accomplished artist, he feels he learns as much about himself and his art while teaching as his students do in their own studies. One of the biggest influences on his recent work was fellow art professor at Xavier, the renowned sculptor, the late John T. Scott. Jennifer Williams is Museum Director and Curator of The McKenna Museum of African American Art.  She received her B.A. in History with a concentration in Art History from Georgia State University in Atlanta, GA. With the guiding spirit of her parent’s dedication of serving others throughout their lives, she moved to New Orleans to serve as an AmeriCorps VISTA coordinating projects with the Tulane University Center for Public Service at a community center in the 7th ward. Serving 3 terms over, her commitment to social justice has grown.  As curator she has the responsibility of finding artists willing and interested in supporting the McKenna by allowing the museum to feature and showcase their work within the city. Funding Use: Funds will be used to help defray the cost of insuring the collection, installation and publicity.  Additional funding over the pledged amount will be used to design and distribute a catalog, for educational programming, for an opening reception, and to defray the cost of  associated fees such as postage for mailing the rewards . Rewards: For their contribution each backer will receive recognition on social media (e.g., the exhibit's Facebook page and website) and his or her name on our list of donors on display at the exhibition. Depending on the amount pledged backers can receive up to three digital copies or prints of a Baby Doll masking by one of three well regarded photographers, an exhibition poster, a commemorative second-line handkerchief and bead throw, an autographed copy of the book, "The Baby Dolls" by Kim Vaz, and a docent tour of the exhibit by one of the organizers.  We would like to thank the three highly regarded photographers for allowing us to use their photographs as gifts to our backers: Romain Breauxis, Phillip Colwart, and Kim Welsh.Biographies of Photographers:Romain Breauxis is originally from France and is an avid explorer of New Orleans and Southern Louisiana culture. Through his photos, he tries to capture some of the richness, joyfulness and fascination that he has witnessed during his adventures!Phillip Colwart was born in Baton Rouge and raised in New Orleans.  He is a Hammond-based professional photographer who contributes his time and photography to the Mardi Gras Indian, Baby Doll and Skull & Bones community.  Having grown to appreciate and value this culture, Phillip gives back to these groups through his photography and thus helps to preserve and perpetuate these traditions.Kim Welsh enjoys capturing the flavor of urban cultural life and celebration in our unique home, New Orleans. She advocates for cultural preservation and aim to understand the unique world view of her subjects and to respectfully translate that using visual imagery. For Welsh, our diverse, vibrant, and spectacular cultural traditions should always be protected and encouraged as they are our treasure which enriches our lives and often goes unappreciated.Profile Image:  A frame from circa 1928-1931 footage of the Baby Dolls on Mardi Gras in New Orleans, Louisiana.  Image is owned by Story Sloane’s Galleries Inc., one of the largest private sources for vintage and historic photography in the south.  For more visit: http://www.sloanegallery.com/Other Ways You Can Help•Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.•Use the Indiegogo share tools.•Leave comments on this page about our campaign.•Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/artaboutbabydolls?ref=hl•Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/artaboutBD•You can make "in-kind" donations.  For example, if you are a caterer, we'd love to discuss with you the opportunity for you to donate your catering services for the opening reception.  If you are a printer, we would love for you to donate to the project by donating your service to print our exhibit poster.•Want to know more? Email us at kimmvaz@gmail.com or rjbechet@yahoo.com

story:
Donald Daedalus (b. 1983, Tacoma, WA). Lives and works in New York and Washington. MFA San Francisco Art Institute; (2012) Lower Manhattan Culural Council; (2011) Franklin Furnace Fund recipient; (2007) En Foco "New Photography" award.

 

"Doppler Shift" in Summary

I'm interested in the Manhattan Grid as an example of an urban development that directs certain kinds human relations. Through formal elements of space, scale, and geometry, this construction informs the kinds of jobs, social classes, exchanges and politics present. (For example, there is very little public space in New York; instead, privately owned public spaces abound, which are often mandated by construction codes, but without the burden of recognizing of individual rights.)

"Doppler Shift" is the second part of an artistic engagement, intervention, and comparison of basic human sensations in this place--sight, sound, feeling of confinement or agoraphobia. I've developed new visual techniques to capture and produce this work, while learning from other artists' (K. Wodiczko, Graffiti Research Lab) research and accomplishments. Using digital video projection to daylight architecture, storefrornts, streets and people of late-night New York, I am creating a panoramic, expanded video environment that will displace images of the city through time and space. The projections will be executed in neighborhoods all over the Manhattan Grid for people who may not regularly encounter contemporary art in the day-to-day or night-to-night schedules. 

This project has received seed funds from the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council and through their network, I hope this project will be have a wide reception. With your support, I can produce this unique work that employs creative new video technologies to address larger social concerns.

 

What I Need...

-Overhead projector & Bulbs 

-Prototyping & equipment such as

   -manufactured fittings
   -buying glass lenses to direct/control light
   -support structure to hold everything together while driving
   -power inverter

-Cables and connectors

-Promotional materials like postcards and flyers to get the word out!

-Web site (EVERY SPONSOR/CONTRIBUTOR WILL BE CREDITED)

-Renting the vehicle for 4 days + test drives - This projector is going to move through Manhattan!

-Paying hired help (no unpaid interns here)

-Taking time off work to make this happen (3-4 weeks prototyping + execution dates)

 

*Without full funding, the number of days will be scaled down and/or a static installation may substitute a mobile projection.

 

...& What You Get

This project has and will continue to generate a lot of work that I'm exchanging for your support.

-Excerpt of part 1 ("Doppelganger Effect")

-85-page four-in-one artist's flipbook

-documentation and announments materials 

-eBook from this year's project that includes documentation, essays, schematics, clippings (pdf or iPad format).

-1-hour DVD of video works that have informed or led up to this project Like all works, previous works informed this project

-Rides in the vehicle during the projection

 

Other Ways You Can Help

-Sending this to others who might be interested
-Posting on Facebook, Twitter, pinterest or full-body tattoos. 
-Send this to your best friend, your rich aunt, your employed friend who talks about becoming an art collector.
-Check out IndieGoGo share tools. 

 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR TIME. 

-DD

story:
ABOUT THE ARTIST:

Visual artist Jolyn Gardner Campbell from Seattle, Washington is on a specific mission to connect people all over the world through the medium of art.  The first stop on this mission will take place this October when Jolyn travels with the group, Artists to Africa, as a teacher representing her discipline of painting.  

ABOUT THE INTERNATIONAL PUBLIC ART QUILT:

Every square on the art quilt is handpainted using paint.  When you send me your message or story, I will artfully transform it into an image, pattern, and or design all inspired by your words.  I like to add metallic paint, jewels, beads, leather and other materials to embellish the square patch and make it pop!  My style is abstract expressionism.  I love generous amounts of color!  Just look at my award winning painting below called "Limbs on a Whim!"  This art quilt will ultimately be left in Ghana as an international gift of art!

It will take a village to make this international public art mission a reality.   

Once all of the messages are gathered together and organized by subject matter I will begin the process of capturing the emotion and tone to design a one of a kind image/layout!  

The individual pieces are then joined together in larger sections and carefully packed for shipping.  Once we reach Ghana, the sections will then be assembled to make one large piece.  Remember, the art quilt will be as big as the number of "ARTicipants!"  

So don't miss this amazing opportunity to be part of this international art quilt!  Become an "ARTicipant" today!

ABOUT THE PERKS:

INTRODUCING THE OFFICIAL IPAQ PRINT!

Get the Official IPAQ mixed media print!  This is a truly special piece with an imprint of Jolyn's actual hand.  Have a keepsake of this amazing project that is sure to be a conversation piece and ultimately a collector's item.  

Bronze "ARTicipant" gets your message on a 5x5 quilt square artfully transformed by me for only $25 plus a postcard with the finished image!

Silver "ARTicipant" gets your message on a 5x10 quilt square artfully transformed by me for only $50 plus a postcard with the finished image!

Gold "ARTicipant" gets your message on a 10x10 quilt square artfully transformed by me for only $100 plus a postcard with the finished image!

Be a girl's best friend as a Diamond "ARTicipant" and you will get everything with the Gold "ARTicipant" perk plus a specially designed Certifiication of "ARTicipation" with your name!

It's takes a Village "ARTicipant" to make it happen!  As such, you will get everything with the Diamond "ARTicipant" perk plus a limited edition poster of the finished image! 

Let's not forget about our Heritage "ARTicipant" which gets everything with the Diamond "ARTicipant" perk plus a signed limited edition 16x20 print of the finished image!

Ultimately, it's about establishing a Legacy "ARTicipant" which gets everything with the Heritage "ARTicipant" perk plus something truly special...

The Legacy "ARTicipant" will receive a 24x24 mini art quilt featuring textiles from Ghana!!  This will be a true collector's item. 

ABOUT A2A:

ARTISTS 2 AFRICA was birthed from decades of artists discussing the prospect of organizing a group journey to Africa tailored specifically for artists and focused on art education. On October 19-30, 2013 we will embark on our second official journey to Ghana West Africa!

The artists will journey into the art villages on the outskirts of Ghana. Various artisans including painters, sculptors, and weavers will be gathered in their workshops to create and collaborate. We will fellowship with the artists and students, visit their workshops to share technique, and explore the creative process, while exchanging our creative ideas with the artisans in the region. An exhibition will be organized featuring the works of each artist. Our focus is to educate and connect through ART.

HOW WILL YOUR FUNDS BE UTILIZED?

The campaign is to assist with acquiring art materials for this project and artists in Africa to use on our visit as we fellowship by creating art. We will be visiting 4 locations where ceramic, wood carving, fabric making and other artforms are taught and produced. We will introduce various art projects and will instruct several groups of artisans and other participants. Funds will assist with art supplies and materials, and small tools. We also plan to document this experience with photography and video as a future educational medium. We hope you will take advantage of this unique opportunity to assist with this project....thank you.Share.Teach.Create!

story:
Here is the merch that should have been exclusively sold on tour. It wasn’t meant to be put online but things don’t always turn out the way we want obviously.
As you can all imagine, the music industry (like every other field) is going to suffer a lot from what’s happening to all of us, and it will take months for technicians, booking agencies, promoters, venues, drivers, musicians, etc…to recover.
We saw bands who performed in empty venues, for their last shows, and stream them so fans can still have a little bit of what could have been a great night.
We salute them, that’s awesome, we wish we had the opportunity to do so, but we were on stage when we heard that show would be our last.
We then decided to ask venues if it would be ok to perform twice every night so maybe 200 people could see us perform, for few more shows, or even for one last show, to let the magic do its work one last time, a little while longer, but it was too late.

We salute those who managed to do it.

Now, we also saw bands using crowdfunding to get out of this mess, we can’t judge that, we know the financial loss, but that’s not something we will do, that doesn’t seem right. All we have is our merch made for you, and it will remain magical no matter what.


We’re thankful we were lucky enough to do half of our tour when some bands we know couldn’t even start, we’re blessed none of us personally knows someone who’s suffering from that virus right now, our thoughts to those who didn’t have that chance, our thoughts to those working 24/7 fighting the disease so we can all be safe as soon as possible.

Stay home, stay safe, we’ll see you very soon. Until then, believe and carry on, always.

story:
Who is Tony?

Tony Guglietti has been called "deliciously goofy" by the New York Times.  The Village Voice has described his dancing as "liquid."  A critic from Dance Insider referred to him as "the great straight hope of modern dance."  We mention these things for a few reasons:

  1. Humble brag. Obviously.
  2. So you can make fun of Tony later about this (Jesse Duval)
  3. So you know this show is legit.  It's gonna be good: we promise.

A little more about Tony: he received his BFA from Tisch School of the Arts at NYU. Upon graduation he became a founding member of Sean Curran Company, with whom he toured regularly across the United States, France, and Germany from 1998-2005. In 2012, Tony returned to Sean Curran Company to tour to Central Asia. Do you actually care about this? Are you still reading?  Tony also performed with Brian Brooks Moving Company, Peter Pucci, and Joanna Mendl Shaw.  do you know who those people are? are you impressed?  Tony has been privileged to dance on some of New York’s finest stages, including Jazz at Lincoln Center, The Metropolitan Opera House, and three seasons at The Joyce Theater. We promise, that's actually a big deal even if you don't know about it.  Now based in the Boston area, Tony is currently dancing with Brian Feigenbaum and Peter DiMuro/Public Displays of Motion, as well as collaborating on a series of duets with Kristin Wagner.

Outside of dance, Tony refs hockey, thinks hot dogs are a perfectly acceptable meal, eats too much fast food, and has absolutely no understanding of the internet and/or technology.  Kristin is writing this for him.  ON A MORE SERIOUS NOTE Tony is an excellent painter (houses, not canvas) so if you need a fresh coat on your living room, check out Steady Guglietti Precision Painting on Facebook.  And, even if you don't really care about anything we wrote about his dance background, he is a pretty good dancer and choreographer.

Who is Town Meeting?

Winner's of the New England Music Award's "2017 Roots Act of the Year", Town Meeting is an folk/Americana/roots band from Boston, MA. Town Meeting is 100% committed to their live show. This is a band that is to be not only heard, but seen and experienced. While they sound great in a studio, to truly understand Town Meeting you must see them live. Playing primarily acoustic instruments they strive to bring the energy of rock and punk bands to a folk show. Town Meeting has had the privilege of warming up crowds for renowned artists such as Bob Dylan, Sturgill Simpson, Willie Nelson, Old Crow Medicine Show, The Avett Brothers, Third Eye Blind, Lettuce, The Dustbowl Revival, and many more. We are thinking you are probably much more impressed by Town Meeting at this point than you are by Tony, and that's fine.  Town Meeting is awesome, except for Russ. Just kidding, Russ, Tony loves you.

What is this show?

Experience in Motion will take place November 9 & 10, 2018 at 8pm at The Dance Complex. Featuring original music by local folk/Americana band Town Meeting, this evening will pair live music and dance for a seamless blending of movement and sound.  Town Meeting is dedicated to providing audiences with a full auditory, visual, and emotional experience.  A series of dance vignettes will accompany the music, pulling from the band’s energy to create equally dynamic movement.  Part music concert and part modern dance concert, the evening will create a unique experience to be enjoyed by both dance and music enthusiasts alike.  The bar remains open in the theater throughout the performance, so even if you don't end up liking the show, you can always just drink a lot of beer.

Tony ran the dance department at The Pomfret School in CT (yes, that is fancy) from 2006-2012, and dance education is still something near and dear to Tony's heart.  He invited some local studios to join us in this show, and set some work on the awesome students of Wilmington Dance Academy (Wilmington, MA) and FreeForm Dance Academy (Westminster, MA). These awesome kiddos were actually really involved in the creation of the pieces, so come see what they made! It might be better than what Tony made.

Doors will open at 7:15pm, and audience are invited to take the floor and listen to a pre-show performance of Town Meeting before the professional dancers take the stage at 8pm.  Pre-sale General Admission tickets will be available online for $18, and there are discounts for students, seniors, and military.  Prices increase at the door, so if you are interested in coming, visit experienceinmotion.eventbrite.com!

What do we need?

Simply put: money!

Dance shows are surprisingly expensive to produce, especially when you are paying every artist involved.  Tony's first priority with this show was to pay the dancers and musicians involved in this show - something that doesn't always happen in the art world.  Currently, all of the money for the production of this show is being paid straight from Tony's pockets.  All money raised by this IndieGoGo will be paid directly to the PEOPLE who are bringing this show to life.

The total of budgeted expenses for this show is just shy of $12,400.  The total projected box office revenue for this show is just over $2,500.  This leaves a net loss of about $10,000 if Tony doesn't find additional financial support.  You can look at the breakdown of expenses in the fancy pie chart below.  All money going to artists is designated in shades of yellow; all other production expenses are in shades of red.  As you can see, this show will provide incredible financial support to over a dozen professionally performing artists in Massachusetts.  Please help support Tony in this mission!

How else can you help?

Are you interested in helping, but do not have the financial means to do so?  We appreciate support of ANY kind!  If you cannot contribute financially, or if you can but you would like to do even more because you're an ANGEL sent from HEAVEN, here are some more ways you can help us out:

  • Volunteer to usher at one of the shows!  We need ushers who are willing to come a little early, help set up, and maintain some order and decorum during the show.  Come be our bouncer!
  • Come to the show!  We are hoping to sell out both nights of this show: join us in the audience and show your support for the arts! We promise you'll have a great time.
  • Spread the word!  Share this campaign with friends of yours who might be able to contribute, and invite them to the show.  We are hoping to widen some circles here and attract more fans for Town Meeting and for modern dance.

Thank you.

Regardless of the size of your contribution or the form that it comes in, thank you for reading this far.  Thank you for taking the time to learn more about this project and about the arts.  Thank you for being a fan of live music and dance.  Thank you, thank you, thank you!

story:
Hi, I am Patricia Missakian, and it never ceases to amaze me that each exploration I do in the Records reveals deeper and deeper truths.

 The Akashic Realm holds the collective Records for all humanity; there are 44 Messengers here who support humanity in the transition into 5th dimension consciousness. The Records held by the dimension of the Akashic Realm goes beyond what anyone can access by visiting their or another’s personal Akashic Records. 

 This oracle is a gateway of direct access to the Akashic Realm Messengers: Guides, Guardians and Teachers from the Akashic Realm who stand ready to support you on your path on this earth.

These cards will awaken in you deep reflection and healing and will unlock the connection between you and the Akashic Realm, opening your ability to access the knowledge the guides, guardians and teachers from the Akashic Realm have for you.

Oracle cards are a simple way in which humans can pass through the veil of the ego and hear their intuition. Each card speaks directly to your soul as you contemplate the imagery and the written messages.

 Each card in this oracle deck brings you detailed messages in both the imaginary and the written content.

The 44 cards contain the following Messengers:

One (1) Guardian: 

The Master Guardian of the Akashic Realm
This powerful mentor has the key to all Akashic Portals 

Three (3) Healing Guides:

They facilitate healing in three specific areas of life: The Cure of Planet, The Cure and Restoration of the Light Body and The Cure and Restoration of the Physical Body. 

Twenty (20) Akashic Teachers:

Each Akashic Teacher has a specific connection to support development in a specific area of life, bringing in a message that feels like a breath of fresh air, yet with the power to change the point of view that have kept you stuck, thus completely transforming the way in which you perceive and respond to life’s challenges. 

Ten (10) Akashic Records Guardians:

The 10 Akashic Records Guardians are extremely important to our development as they ease the connection between Soul and nature Elements. 

 Ten (10) Akashic Records Guides:

The goal of the Akashic Records Guides is to ease the learning process as we learn to feel our feelings/emotions and living as humans in a physical body. Each Guide brings specific advice on how to be a spiritual being having a human experience.

Try a reading! 


Take a moment to tune in and ask a question for the Akashic Realm Messengers.
Hit the play button below and pause to pick a card.

How this Oracle was Created:

First I received the messages from the 44 Messengers from the Akashic Realm.

Then, I received the insight for the person who would be able to hold the correct interpretation of the Messengers and bring them to life in beautiful illustrations, this magical person is one of my very own students in the Akashic Records Institute. The magnificent artist, Graca Santos. And then the circle was complete.

For the past several months Graca and I have gathered weekly and together journey to the Akashic Realm to meet each Messenger. Below are some of the images of the Messengers that have already come through.

Now we are bringing 44 Messengers from the Akashic Realm, ready to guide and support us all!

BONUS: Full Course: Luminosity

Everyone who pledges a deck or more will receive the Full Course: Luminosity - Working With The Akashic Realm Messengers™ To Prepare For The Coming Cosmic Upgrade

 

 

The Creator and The Artist:

The Creator: Patricia Missakian is an  international speaker, author and Akashic Records Mentor.

She is the founder of the Akashic Records Institute, a school for spiritual development that certifies students as Akashic Records Practitioners and/or Global Healing Practitioners, with classes in both Portuguese and English.

She is the creator of this body of work: Akashic Realm Messengers™ Oracle Deck and Sacred Crystal Codes™ Oracle Deck and Sacred Crystal Codes™ book.

Her MISSION is to awaken and empower people to live their soul purpose.

The Artist: Graça Santos is an artist who is also trained in Psychology that specializes in quantum emotional reprogramming.

In each mandala or portrait of the human face that she creates she connects with the higher self of the person, contemplating the loving look from the Creator.

This was the same type of experience she had as she connected with each of the Messengers in the Akashic Realm Messengers™ Oracle Deck and trusts that her work will touch people's souls and help them realign with their Soul’s.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for backing this project by pre-ordering your Oracle Deck and Add Ons.


And, if you'd like to help me out, but can't make a pledge, that is A-okay! You can help by reaching out to your friends and family and share this campaign!

Just share this page link (www.AkashicRealm.com) on your social media, Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and help me spread the word.

Or click on the icons at the top of the page to instantly share.

If you are a blogger or someone with a big community, I would love to get together with you and share the magic of the Akashic Realm Messengers™ with your tribe! I am available for interviews or guest blogging.

If there's anything else you need or want to ask me about, feel free to leave a comment, I'll be stalking my campaign for the next days so I will be here for you!

P.S. Don't forget to follow my Facebook page - Akashic Records Institute where I will share readings, healings, and prize drawings during the campaign! Go here to join now for FREE.

Follow the “Akashic Realm Messengers™ Oracle Deck project” on our Akashic Records Institute Instagram Account, FB Account and Youtube account.  

Shipping

We know how upsetting steep shipping charges are. While we can’t control USPS costs we are only asking you to help with the actual cost to ship your items to you and to thank you for helping with the shipping I am gifting you a very special Akashic Clearing Session; a $22 value.

Risks & Challenges

This Campaign has required very detailed planning, development, and coordination with the artist and copywriter, translators and printers. I feel confident in my ability to publish this deck and fulfill rewards on time by February 2020.

I always make sure to realistically account for shipping costs and the additional costs for stretch goals. I've shipped many items worldwide from my previous Campaigns and now have an assistant (my hubby). We're no strangers to large shipping volumes worldwide. :)

The challenges are found in unforeseen issues involving mishaps in the printing or shipping of the decks to Los Angeles. We have back up plans in place in case any of the businesses we are dealing with should have severe issues.

story:
Hello all!

My name is Hailey Guzik. I am an emerging artist with Maritime roots currently living in Montreal, Quebec.

Since graduating in May 2017, I have been working on a new body of work titled Translocations with generous support from Artsnb New Brunswick Arts Board. My project period is at it's end but I'm not ready to call it quits! In order to continue, I need your support. Funds raised through this campaign will go directly to covering my next year of studio and material costs. It will also help me finance the production of current paintings for an upcoming show in Spring 2018. 

I have put together a selection of small affordable poster quality prints and hand-made vinyl stickers for you to choose from, as a thank you for your chosen level of support. You can also receive an original 5x7" oil painting study by sending me a picture of a special view: a street you like, your favourite tree, an old family photo of you at the beach, that snow pile you see across from the bus stop melting and growing as winter progresses... basically whatever connects you to your immediate surroundings!

If you are unable to support, please consider sharing this campaign with friends and family. Any level of support is greatly appreciated. Everyone who shares this campaign will be entered into a draw for a chance to win an original 5x7" oil painting study. Just make sure to tag me so I know!

This project means everything to me as a emerging artist. Getting my feet on the ground and having the space to continue making new projects is a huge privilege that I do not take lightly. It is equally important for me to acknowledge the great amount of support and encouragement I have received from friends, and loved ones. I wouldn't be able to do any of this without you.

See more at: https://www.instagram.com/hailey_guzik_/

Thanks,

Hailey

xx

story:
30. eine retrospektive. eine ausstellung. eine feier:

junge, wie die zeit vergeht. zum 30. geburtstag möchte ich resümieren und mit einer ausstellung kleine, besondere perlen ans tageslicht bringen, die meinen bisherigen weg begleitet haben. vor allem experimentelle arbeiten, als auch landschaftsfotografien sowie portraits werden zu sehen sein. erstmalig mogeln sich auch einige illustrationen unter. ein tribut an die merkwürdigkeiten des lebens.

für diesen anlass könnte es keinen besseren ort geben als die gemütliche 'galerie studio st. st.'  galeristin juwelia wird zur vernissage eine bezaubernde show hinlegen. getränke und häppchen gibt es auch. ihr seid natürlich alle eingeladen!

ich würde mich riesig freuen, wenn ihr mir helft, die ausstellung auf die beine zu stellen! dafür danke ich euch von herzen.


ohne moos, nix los:

für die ausstellung möchte ich gerne brandneue arbeiten drucken und alte werke frisch aufbereiten. ca. 40 bilder wird die ausstellung umfassen. hier schlüssele ich euch mal kurz auf, wofür das geld benötigt wird:

  • 600 € fotodrucke und rahmen
  • 50 € für die raummiete an die galeristin 'juwelia'
  • 10 € transportkosten

tolle sachen für tolle menschen:

diese wunderbaren dinge könnt ihr euch als dankeschön aussuchen!
natürlich ist es auch möglich einfach so einen betrag beizusteuren.



kommen, feiern und staunen:

die ausstellung '30 ~ eine retrospektive' wird an meinem geburtstag eröffnet.
vernissage: fr. 09.10.2015 ab 20:00 uhr
öffnungszeiten: fr. & sa. 20:00 bis 00:00 uhr 
galerie studio st. st., sanderstraße 26, 12047 berlin
09.10. - 07.11.2015

der eintritt ist natürlich frei.
ich freue mich unwahrscheinlich auf euch!

hier geht's zum facebook-event.

für diesen anlass könnte es keinen besseren ort geben als die gemütliche 'galerie studio st. st.'  galeristin juwelia wird zur vernissage eine bezaubernde show hinlegen. getränke und häppchen gibt es auch. ihr seid natürlich alle eingeladen!
ich würde mich riesig freuen, wenn ihr mir helft, die ausstellung auf die beine zu stellen! dafür danke ich euch von herzen.
   ohne moos, nix los: für die ausstellung möchte ich gerne brandneue arbeiten drucken und alte werke frisch aufbereiten. ca. 40 bilder wird die ausstellung umfassen. hier schlüssele ich euch mal kurz auf, wofür das geld benötigt wird:  600 € fotodrucke und rahmen 50 € für die raummiete an die galeristin 'juwelia' 10 € transportkosten 
   
tolle sachen für tolle menschen:



diese wunderbaren dinge könnt ihr euch als dankeschön aussuchen!natürlich ist es auch möglich einfach so einen betrag beizusteuren.




kommen, feiern und staunen:die ausstellung '30 ~ eine retrospektive' wird an meinem geburtstag eröffnet.vernissage: fr. 09.10.2015 ab 20:00 uhröffnungszeiten: fr. & sa. 20:00 bis 00:00 uhr galerie studio st. st., sanderstraße 26, 12047 berlin09.10. - 07.11.2015der eintritt ist natürlich frei.ich freue mich unwahrscheinlich auf euch!hier geht's zum facebook-event.

story:
ANALOG TO DIGITAL (Phase I)

Introduction and Goals

I am a multi-media artist who has been engaged in pioneering work with interactive systems and video installation since the early nineteen-eighties. You can learn more about me here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miroslaw_Rogala.

Over the past thirty years, I have accumulated a vast video library, an archive of my work dating back to the early years of video. Aside from the amount of space this takes up and the cost of storage, I am concerned about preserving this work for the future and about transferring it to a format that is compatible with present-day equipment so I can continue to share it with the public.

The cost (and risk) of sending these tapes out to a production house for transfer is steep and prohibitive. What I propose instead is to purchase the equipment necessary for the transfer and to hire one or two assistants to aid me with this enormous task. I am estimating that the initial cost will be around twenty thousand dollars, which is the amount I am hoping to raise and the reason I am asking for your support. 

Why This is Important

This project is about historic preservation. Work that I have archived in my library documents some of the earliest experiments combining video with computers to create viewer interactive installations. These date back to a time when many of the applications we take for granted today had not been invented and programming skills were required to produce the most basic effects. 

I also want to preserve my collaborations with other artists. For example, I have hours of tape documenting Chicago Imagist painter Ed Paschke working in his studio as well as interviews with him and other rare footage. I have also worked with Carolee Schneemann, Merce Cunningham, Shigeko Kubota and many other artists, performers and musicians, all captured on tape in my library. I even have unpublished footage of Czeslaw Niemen, the iconic singer who is as revered in Poland as Elvis is in the United States.

Over the years I have created over three hundred analog video tapes in several different formats, the most popular being 8mm, Betamax SP and ¾” SP and non-SP. To hire professionals to digitize these tapes costs over $100 per hour not including transportation costs, if the playback equipment to do the job is even available. What’s worse, the tapes themselves are fragile and will eventually deteriorate. My early tapes are getting close to their expiration date, so I am in a race with time to digitize the archive before it is lost forever. 

Transferring this treasure trove of analog material to digital media will also make it accessible to new generations of viewers, researchers and art historians. My ultimate goal is to set up a digital database that includes metadata that can be shared with museums, libraries and other institutions worldwide.


Rewards for Donors

Donors will receive valuable premiums: signed DVDs of video and multi-media work or signed and numbered digital prints. Some of the larger pieces will be printed on canvas; each uniquely altered with acrylic paint and signed.

Please Share

You can also help by sharing this with friends, acquaintances and with anyone who is a fan of cutting-edge digital artwork. Thank you!

story:
Welcome to Stack of Fives!

Stack of Fives is a photographic exploration of story-telling, in which artists are prompted to push the boundaries of their creative process through the use of tools they are unaccustomed with. The result is a collection of large-scale photographs that approach story-telling in new and unexpected ways.  

We are proud to have been selected by see | me to present this collection for the first time in the see | me Exhibition Space this winter in NYC, accompanied by an original devised theatre performance. But we need your help.

To make this project possible, we need to raise $7000 to pay for large format prints and framing, as well as to compensate the artists that will perform at the show’s opening. So we're turning to our friends, families and the artistic community to ask for contributions. Join us in bringing Stack of Fives to life!

More Details? Yes Please!

What if a writer’s only tool for creation was a drum set? What if the drummer was forced to express himself using a paint brush? What if the painter used actors as colors and the stage as a canvas? The musician expresses life with sound, the dancer with movement, the sculptor with shapes and the writer with words. Every artist employs a unique vocabulary and set of tools to share their story. These tools define their voice and in turn, their voice defines them.

But what happens when artists, from varying disciplines, are forced to tell a story with the tools of a medium they aren’t trained in? This is the question Stack of Fives explores.

Back in 2012, we partnered with MassBliss and asked 15 artists from different fields, ranging from theatre directors to graffiti artists, to tell a story through a simple format imposed to them: 1 panoramic photograph composed of 5 photographs of the same person or group of people, merged together into a single landscape. The result will be unveiled at the Stack of Fives World Premiere Exhibition.

We are proud to announce that see | me has offered to showcase Stack of Fives in their see | me Exhibition Space in Long Island City, starting on December 5th, 2014. see | me is an online community created by a group of NYC artists that connects over a million artists, photographers and enthusiasts to a worldwide audience, both online and through live events and exhibitions.

On December 5th and 6th, we will hold special opening night events featuring an original theatre piece, directed by Simón Adinia Hanukai, and based on the stories told in the Stack of Fives photographs.

What We Need Funds For

We need your help to bring Stack of Fives to life and in front of an audience! We want to be transparent with you about our costs.* We are raising funds for the following:

Large-scale photographic prints (10 x $450) = $4500

Artist fees for 15 performers = $2500

TOTAL = $7000

*We are happy to share a more detailed budget upon request.

If you are interested in being one of our private donors by making a larger tax deductible donation, please contact us at stackoffives@gmail.com

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Of course, there are other ways you can help!

    • Please spread the word to others who might be interested in supporting us;
    • If you or someone you know have personal connections with potential sponsors, especially photo printing companies, please let us know;
    • Please notify us if you know of press, industry or media outlets that may be interested in Stack of Fives;
    • Finally, as we get closer to the exhibition, please spread the word!

    Please do not hesitate to contact us at stackoffives@gmail.com.

    On behalf of the entire team, we’d like to thank you for your support. Your help allows us to bring the work of dozens of artists to life and in front of an audience!

    The Stack of Fives Team and Collaborating Artists

    The Creative Team

    Jonathan Camuzeaux - Creator, Photographer

    Andrew Belcher - Creator, Producer

    The Lead Collaborating Artists

    Ito Aghayere, Theodore Bouloukos, Tony and Cindy Cahill, Richard Cherneff, Donovan W. Christie Jr., Simón Adinia Hanukai, Marilee Herring, Mayu Iwasaki, Anita Kirpalani, Jen Kosky, Jimmy Maize, Leemore Malka, Miranda Hope Shea, Jeri Silverman, Biniam Tekola

    The see | me Exhibit Team

    Mayu Iwasaki - Lead Event Producer

    Simón Adinia Hanukai - Performance Director

    James Puckett - MassBliss Partnership Coordinator

    The Producing Partners

    MassBliss

    see | me

    More Collaborating Artists!

    Jon M.J. Cooper, Eloise Eonnet, Evan Garrett, Janouke Goosen, Brandon Hogstad, Mary-Kate Hudson, Wei-Yi Lin, Matt Mauer, Flavie Peynot, Felipe Vara de Rey, Johnny Segalla, Samantha Slater, Sonia Villani, Brenda Zamora

story:
Overview

  The Black Light Room  of Phi Sigma Kappa  was created by Rennselaer Civil Engineering Student Ned Cleland between 1970-1971, where it glowingly loomed over Hoosick Street in Troy, New York for the next three decades.  When our Chapter House met the wrecking ball in 2006, these psychedelic relics were saved, with the intention of restoring and re-installing the work in a future location.  

THAT TIME IS NOW!

With the purchase of our new Chapter House, in 2011, the Black Light Room has found a new home, in the stained-glass sanctuary of the St. Frances de Sales Church, on Congress Avenue in Troy, NY.  

Restoration Efforts have been on-going over the past two year's, but we need your financial help to make this vision a reality for this for Alumni Weekend, this October.

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

The $4000 in funding is to be used to direct, out of pocket, expenses related to the completion of this artistic restoration project.  All time and labour will be provided on a volunteer basis by project co-ordinator and former Black Light Room denizen, Bill Saunders (RPI '86  BSME), and the brotherhood of Phi Sigma Kappa, Gamma Tetarton Chapter.

The scope of this project is, , is as follows:

1). Ceiling ( 12'x16') Patch, Repaint, and Assemble existing ceiling panels  into six  (4'x8') portable, free standing, framed modular units. Mount and Frame two original posters.



 2). Wiring and Lighting, Installation materials.


3).  Mounting, framing, and touch up of :

        a) Existing Volcano Section.

        b) Existing Caterpillar Section.

        c),  Cabinet door.


4). Cargo Van Rental for transportation of completed panels from his home studio in New Haven, Ct, to the Chapter House in Troy, NY.

5). Re-creation of the  Cloud Wall,  assembled into two (4'x8') free standing, modular units (with help of active Brotherhood and Pledges)

6. Re-creation of the Door.


Note:  This project incorporates  all of the salvage-worthy material saved from the Black Light Room.  Of course, there is more that can be re-created -- there are great photos of the original room to work from --- maybe if we exceed the goal!


Preview

The first half of the ceiling was installed in the Sanctuary this past Easter.

Here is a nibble ....the installation will unfold accordingly..

Thanks for your support in bringing this historic psychedelic outsider 'art'-ifact into the light, where it may be appreciated for years to come...
